The shape is oval to irregular, with a single contiguous white area and crisped edges. The cook might be sliding the egg onto a plate, sprinkling salt/pepper, and turning off the heat.

frying_fish.progress_description: Start or intermediate: Raw or thawed fish fillet sits in oil or batter; surface is pale, moist, and glistening; edges not colored yet. As frying proceeds: the oil sizzles, bubbles cling to the coating, and a thin crust forms; color at the edges darkens slightly while the center remains translucent and steamy; the fillet may puff or curl. The cook uses tongs or a spatula, adjusts heat, and turns pieces to cook more evenly.
frying_fish.finished_description: End state: evenly browned, crisp crust with a golden surface; fillets slightly compacted and shrunk. Exterior is dry and crackly in places; interior is opaque white, flaky, and juicy. Oil sheen may be present. Size reduced modestly; edges may curl. For the cook: remove from heat, drain on paper towels or a rack, rest briefly, then plate and serve.

frying_plantain.progress_description: Start state: peeled plantains sliced into coins or diagonals; uniform thickness; skin color ranges from green to yellow-green; flesh is firm and opaque. In-progress: pieces immersed in hot oil; surface appears glossy and slick with oil; active steaming and bubbling around edges; color remains pale to light creamy as starch softens; edges may curl and soften; pan handler uses tongs or spatula to flip and rotate pieces, maintaining gentle agitation.
frying_plantain.finished_description: End state: fried plantains are a golden to amber-brown exterior, with crisp edges and a soft, tender center (color/texture vary with ripeness and cut). Slices may be round coins, lengthwise strips, or twice-fried tostones—flat and very crisp. They should be drained on paper towels after frying. The cook is likely transferring to a plate, lightly salting, and serving with sauces or accompaniments (beans, rice, salsa).

frying_tofu.progress_description: State descriptions (start/intermediate): tofu cubes/slabs are pale white to light tan, surfaces glossy and moist, edges smooth or slightly rounded; centers may be translucent. In progress: pieces sit or drift in oil; small bubbles cling to surfaces; steam rises; surface moisture evaporates; some corners begin to firm, while others remain soft, not yet crisp. Cook actions: preheating oil, laying pieces in, turning with tongs or spatula, spacing apart, adjusting heat to prevent sticking.
frying_tofu.finished_description: End state: tofu pieces are evenly golden-brown with a crisp exterior and slightly dry surface; edges are crisp. Size may shrink slightly; blocks stay roughly the original shape. Interior remains soft or custardy inside, depending on firmness. Surface may show caramelized spots. Done when all sides are browned and no longer soggy. The cook may remove to paper towels to drain briefly, then plate or toss with sauce.

frying_bread.progress_description: Start/intermediate stages: a pale bread slice lies on a hot, lightly oiled pan; the surface is moist and glossy with tiny bubbles; edges may curl and soften as steam escapes. The cook uses a spatula to press for full contact, shifts the slice to distribute heat, and may flip to monitor underside during the cooking interval.
frying_bread.finished_description: End state of frying bread: a roughly round or oblong piece with slightly puffed, blistered surface. Exterior golden-brown to amber, with crisp, thin crust and darker edges; interior soft, airy crumb just barely cooked through. It may have expanded a bit in thickness and diameter due to steam, yet retains the original shape. The cook usually drains excess oil on paper towels, then serves warm, optionally sliced and topped.

frying_mushroom.progress_description: At start or during cooking, mushrooms appear raw or partly cooked: whole, halved, or sliced into coins; sizes range from tiny to medium. Surfaces stay moist and glossy; caps may be translucent at edges as texture softens. In progress, oil sizzles and droplets bead; mushrooms shrink slightly and release juices. The cook stirs, flips, or spreads pieces in a single layer with a spatula or tongs, adjusting heat as needed.
frying_mushroom.finished_description: End state: sliced mushrooms are golden-brown to deep caramel, shrunken (~30–50%), with crisp edges and a tender interior; surface lightly glossy from retained oil. Color is even, not raw or pale, with reduced moisture and no visible liquid pooling. They have a pleasant nutty aroma; texture ranges from softly chewy to crisp around edges. The cook is likely removing them from heat, draining excess oil, and plating or tossing into a dish.

frying_tomato.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: tomato pieces in hot oil hiss and release steam; shapes range from halves or slices holding shape to flattening with centers pressed. Colors shift from bright red to pinkish, with a translucent, glossy surface as membranes soften. Outer edges blister and soften; interior remains somewhat firm but juicier, seeds loosening. The cook stirs or flips, spreads pieces for even contact, and adjusts heat, possibly sprinkling salt or herbs.
frying_tomato.finished_description: End state: Tomato pieces are softened, mostly broken down into a glossy, jammy sauce; skins blistered or loosened; edges lightly caramelized to golden-brown; color ranges from bright red to copper; liquid reduced to a cohesive glaze; texture varies from chunky to smooth, depending on slice size. When done, the cook might remove from heat, drain excess oil on paper towels, plate or add to a dish, and/or deglaze or stir into a sauce.

frying_rice.progress_description: Start/intermediate frying state: a shallow, oiled pan over heat with sizzling moisture. Rice grains are mostly white, some translucent, surface slick with oil; edges blister or show uneven toasting; occasional clumps form as starch is released. Steam rises and grains may crackle softly. The cook keeps stirring/tossing with a spatula, spreading grains for even contact, adjusting heat, and continually separating clumps as color and texture begin to change but not yet reach a final fry.
frying_rice.finished_description: End state of fried rice: each grain mostly separate, lightly glossy and golden-brown, not mushy. Grains retain bite; surface slightly crisp on the edges. Color from soy/oil; small bits of scrambled egg, peas/carrots, and green onions visible and evenly dispersed. Aroma of sesame/soy oil. The cook typically does a final toss, turns off heat, then plates or serves in bowls, possibly garnishing with scallions or sesame seeds.

frying_sausage.progress_description: In start/intermediate frying: sausage pieces sit in hot oil, edges begin curling, casings tighten and split slightly, and the exterior shifts from pale pink to light gray with translucent fat glistening; the pieces may swell slightly. Bubbles rise as moisture and fat render; surfaces gloss with oil. The center remains noticeably pinkish and cooler. A cook may flip, roll, or turn pieces with tongs, adjust heat, and separate pieces to promote even contact.
frying_sausage.finished_description: End state: sausages are browned and evenly caramelized, slightly curved and plump, with a crisp exterior and a juicy, opaque interior. Outer surface may blister; color ranges tan to deep brown. Safe internal temp about 160°F (71°C) for pork. After frying, the cook rests them on paper towels to drain fat, then slices or serves on buns with condiments.

frying_batter.progress_description: During frying, batter appears as irregular blobs and ribbons in hot oil. Some droplets float briefly, then rise and assume softly rounded shapes. The surface is pale, milky, and glossy, with many small bubbles breaking the top and occasional expanding blisters. Edges look gently lifted but still flexible. As time passes, pieces jiggle, swell subtly, and flatten when poked. The cook uses a slotted spoon to drop batter, regulate heat, and turn pieces as they set.
frying_batter.finished_description: End state: battered pieces emerge golden-brown and crisp, with an irregular, puffed crust and air pockets. Exterior is dry-crackly to blistered; color ranges from light golden to deep amber. Interior is tender, fully cooked, and steamy. Shapes vary: dropped blobs, tubes, rings. After frying, the cook drains on paper towels, cools briefly, and may dust with sugar, salt, or glaze, then serves or continues with accompanying toppings.

frying_paneer.progress_description: Start state: paneer cubes/strips are pale ivory blocks; surfaces smooth, edges sharp. During progress, moisture beads on surface; a sheen appears; edges may curl slightly as moisture evaporates. In oil, small bubbles cling to each piece; some pieces begin to darken at the edges but remain pale overall. Pieces may float or drift, maintaining their shape but becoming less uniform. The cook uses tongs to turn and separate pieces, adjusting heat to avoid sticking or burning.
frying_paneer.finished_description: End state: Paneer cubes are evenly golden-brown on the outside with a crisp, lightly blistered crust. The interior stays soft, chewy, and airy, slightly spongy from moisture loss; pieces may puff a bit at the centers. Size is similar to the starting piece, with minimal shrinkage. They’re surface-dry and oil-free. Usually next: drain on paper towels, then plate with curry or chutney, garnish, or serve.

frying_eggplant.progress_description: Raw or cut eggplant slices are oval with glossy purple skin and pale, fibrous flesh, about 4–8 mm thick. In progress, the oil is hot and shimmering; bubbles form around and beneath slices as moisture escapes. The flesh turns translucent in places and softens; surfaces appear glossy and slightly wrinkled; edges may curl. The cook uses tongs to turn, move, or separate slices, and adjusts heat or crowding as frying continues, with steam and hiss.
frying_eggplant.finished_description: End state: eggplant pieces are golden brown to deep amber, crusty outside with slight blistering; interior is tender and creamy; edges crisp; surface may glisten with light oil; size slightly reduced from raw due to shrinkage; shape remains slices or bite-sized chunks, often evenly cooked. The finished dish typically drains on paper towels or a rack, then plates or tosses with salt, pepper, oil, or sauce, and serves hot.

frying_shallot.progress_description: Start states: raw shallots are pale, thinly sliced into rings or shards. In-progress: edges become translucent and glossy; pieces soften and slightly curl; moisture beads and steams off; slices hold shape for now; a gentle sizzle appears as oil coats surfaces. The color shifts from white to pale pink-tinted as it heats. The cook loosens, stirs, and spreads the slices for even contact, adjusting heat to prevent sticking or scorching.
frying_shallot.finished_description: End state: shallots are golden amber to deep brown, crisp on the outside and tender inside; rings separated and curled, pieces shrunk in size. Color ranges from light gold to dark caramel. Texture is dry-crisp with slight translucence near the center. Aroma is toasty and sweet. The cook is likely draining on paper towels, then plating or tossing into a dish as a garnish or finishing component.

frying_beef.progress_description: At the start, beef pieces are raw, pinkish-red, with a glossy surface. As frying begins, sizzle appears and fat renders; edges brown and curl slightly while the interior remains reddish. Moisture evaporates and steam rises; the surface develops a light crust and browning patches from Maillard reaction. Pieces shrink marginally and may sit unevenly as heat distributes. The cook flips, moves, and presses for even contact, adjusting heat to control searing.
frying_beef.finished_description: End state: beef presents a browned, seared exterior with shape retained and a dry to lightly glossy crust; interior color matches doneness (rare: warm red center; medium: pink; well-done: gray throughout). Shrinkage may occur; fat rendered and surface may be drier. Texture ranges from juicy to firmer based on doneness. Post-fry, the cook rests the meat, then plates or slices it, drains excess fat, and adds sauce or accompaniments.

frying_vegetable.progress_description: Start state: vegetable pieces—uniform shape and size (sliced, diced, or julienned), raw and pale, moisture visible on surfaces. In progress: oil sizzles, small bubbles cling to edges; surfaces look slick and glisten as heat loosens moisture. Color shifts to translucent or slightly opaque; edges soften, some curling or splitting; texture remains firm but yielding. The cook stirs, flips, and spreads pieces for even contact, while monitoring color and cooking pace.
frying_vegetable.finished_description: End state: Vegetables are tender yet with a slight crisp edge; surface gloss from oil; color ranges from bright fresh to golden-brown, with caramelized spots. Shrinkage occurs; edges may curl or blister; interior softened; steam pockets reduced. Size reduced modestly; pieces might be more uniform. After frying, the cook drains excess oil on paper towels or a rack, then plates, seasons, and serves, possibly tossing with salt, pepper, herbs, or sauce.

frying_shrimp.progress_description: Start: shrimp are elongated, translucent gray, with a wet sheen and no crust. In progress, the edges begin to pink and the surface firms while the centers stay semi-translucent; batter or crust may billow or cling in ridges. Oil sizzles with rising bubbles around the pieces. Shrimp may curl, shrink slightly, and moisture escapes. The cook flips or nudges pieces, adjusts heat, and monitors evenness.
frying_shrimp.finished_description: End state: shrimp are opaque pink-orange, evenly colored, with a slight golden crust. They curl into a loose “C” shape, are firm but tender to bite, and the surface glistens with a thin oil film; any batter or coating is crisp but not burned. Size is marginally reduced from raw. The cook is likely draining on paper towels or a rack, then plating or tossing with sauce before serving.

frying_ginger.progress_description: Raw ginger slices or matchsticks in warm oil: thin edges opaque to translucent, flesh pale tan with fibrous lines. In progress, pieces soften and curl slightly, surfaces glistening and moist, small bubbles cling to rims. Oil shimmers and sizzles around them; steam fogs the pan; aroma intensifies. The cook stirs, spreads pieces evenly, adjusts heat, or flips segments, watching for even sizzle and avoiding crowding.
frying_ginger.finished_description: End state: thin ginger slices or julienne turn golden to light amber, with edges crisp and centers tender; may be translucent to slightly opaque and curling slightly. They shrink modestly in length (roughly 5–20%), surface glossy from oil, aroma sweet-spicy. If fried longer, they become fully crisp and brittle. After frying, the cook lifts them with a slotted spoon, drains on paper towels, then uses them immediately in a dish or as a garnish.

frying_okra.progress_description: Start/intermediate frying states of okra: green, ridged pods or sliced rounds; exterior moisture visible; interior flesh exposed on cut surfaces. In progress, oil sizzles around pieces; mucilage makes surfaces glisten; steam escapes. If battered or breaded, patches cling in a rough coating. Tiny bubbles form at edges; light splatter from moisture. Some pieces stay submerged while others rise toward the surface as heat continues.
frying_okra.finished_description: End state of fried okra: pods (whole or sliced), about 1–3 inches long, coated in a crackly golden-brown crust (cornmeal or batter) that clings to the ridges. The exterior is crisp and firm; the interior is thoroughly heated, tender, greenish, with moisture reduced. Doneness is a crunchy exterior with a soft inside. After frying, the cook drains on paper towels, then plates and serves with dipping sauce or seasoning.

frying_pork.progress_description: Start: pale pink pork chunks with visible marbling sit in hot oil; surface moist, edges pale; oil sizzles. Intermediate: sizzle intensifies; outer surfaces white-to-light-tan as fat begins to render; edges curl; meat contracts slightly; bubbles surround pieces; steam rises. The cook uses tongs to flip and reposition for even contact, adjusts heat, and keeps pieces moving for uniform progression.
frying_pork.finished_description: End state of frying pork: exterior golden-brown with a crisp surface; shape and size slightly reduced from shrinkage; interior fully cooked, opaque, pale gray-white rather than pink; juices clear or barely tinted. Texture should be firm yet tender, not dry or gummy. Surface has a light oil sheen. Typical doneness temperatures: whole cuts 145°F (63°C) with a rest; ground pork 160°F (71°C). The cook often rests, drains excess oil, then plates or slices for serving.

frying_banana.progress_description: Start/intermediate frying states of banana: peeled bananas cut into halves or slices; raw color pale yellow to white. In pan, oil sizzles and bubbles around edges; surface becomes glossy and moist. Slices may curl, edges lift, and centers start to soften while remaining somewhat firm. Steam escapes; small bubbles form within the fruit as moisture releases. The cook tilts pan, flips pieces, and adjusts heat to maintain even sizzle, without describing final color or texture.
frying_banana.finished_description: End state: fried banana shows golden-brown to amber color, with a light, crisp exterior and a warm, soft, creamy interior. Slight shrinkage occurs as moisture reduces; edges may be darker or blistered. Shape stays curved if whole, or flat/halved if sliced. The cook typically removes from heat, rests briefly, and plates it—often with syrup, cinnamon, or ice cream.

frying_cauliflower.progress_description: In the early stage, cauliflower florets are pale white, uniform size, dry, and separated, laid in a hot oil pan. As it progresses, surfaces glisten with oil, moisture sizzles, and tiny bubbles cling to the uneven nooks. Florets may curl slightly and soften at the tips; color remains light, with pale translucence around edges. The cook stirs or turns pieces with tongs, ensuring even contact and preventing crowding, while streams of steam escape.
frying_cauliflower.finished_description: End state: florets are golden brown with crisp, blistered edges; outer crust is dry and crisp while the inside is tender but not mushy. Size remains bite sized; some shrinkage from moisture. Color range from tan to deep caramel. Surface may show speckled browning; minimal oil sheen. The cauliflower should be mostly dry, not soggy. The cook is likely removing from oil, draining on paper towels or a rack, then plating or tossing with sauce.

frying_carrot.progress_description: Carrot pieces (sticks or coins) sit raw and glossy in hot oil. In-progress visuals show bright orange with translucent centers, slight softening, and curling edges; surfaces slick with oil. Tiny bubbles and steam rise as they sizzle. Pieces stay relatively firm, not yet tender. The cook uses tongs or a spatula to flip and shuffle, keeping heat even and spacing between pieces.
frying_carrot.finished_description: End state: carrot pieces (sticks or coins) are golden-brown, with crisp exterior edges and tender interior. Slight shrinkage and curling may occur; surface is dry to the touch, not translucent. Color amber to deep tan; aroma nutty. Size reduces 5–15% depending on thickness. After frying, the cook drains on paper towels, then seasons or tosses with salt/spices, and plates for serving.

frying_steak.progress_description: Start: raw, thick steak sinks into a hot pan; surface wet, interior bright red, fat intact; sizzle erupts as moisture escapes. Intermediate: crust begins as Maillard browning, pale tan edges, edges curl; juices bead on surface; fat renders to a glossy film; shape stays broad with slight shrinkage. Actions: lay it down, press gently for contact, flip with tongs, adjust heat to maintain steady sizzle, rotate for even searing.
frying_steak.finished_description: End state: a steak with a caramel-brown, evenly seared crust; edge-to-edge Maillard; slight shrinkage from pan; exterior crisp, interior gradient from pink to brown, depending on doneness; juices redistributed but still moist inside; fat rendered and shiny. The person is likely resting the steak on a warm plate for five to ten minutes, then slicing or plating, possibly tented with foil and tasting or serving with sauce.

frying_meat.progress_description: Start or intermediate frying meat: irregular slices or chunks in a hot pan. Surfaces transition from glossy pink-red interiors to opaque, with the outer layer showing pale tan as browning begins. Edges may curl, fat renders and pools, and moisture beads on the surface while steam and a sizzle rise. The cook uses tongs to turn, separate pieces, and adjust heat or spacing to maintain contact and prevent sticking and uneven cooking.
frying_meat.finished_description: End state: meat shows a golden-to-dark-brown crust from Maillard reaction, with crisp edges and a surface moisture that’s mostly evaporated. The interior is cooked to the intended doneness (poultry fully opaque; beef can be pink to brown). It typically shrinks slightly as fat and water render. After frying, the cook may rest the meat, slice or plate it, serve with sauce, and/or wipe the pan clean.

frying_pepper.progress_description: Starting or in-progress frying of pepper shows glossy, oil-flecked slices in a hot pan. Color shifts from bright green or red toward olive as moisture evaporates; edges soften and curl slightly. Pieces may stay large or shrink a bit, and some overlap. Surfaces glisten, with bubbles from sizzling. Seeds loosen; steam rises and juices bead on the skin. The cook tilts or stirs with a spatula, moving peppers as heat marks the process.
frying_pepper.finished_description: End state: pepper pieces softened with blistered, lightly charred skins; colors stay bright (red/orange/yellow/green) under a glossy oil sheen; edges curl and some pieces become translucent at the margins; interior tender but not mushy; moisture reduced; seeds loosened if not removed. Aromas are sweet and toasty. The cook is likely tossing them in oil, scraping the pan, tasting, or transferring to a dish or plate.

peeling_banana.progress_description: At the start, the banana is intact and curved, 6–8 inches long, with yellow skin and a tip if underripe, and a firm, glossy texture. In mid-peel, the stem end is grasped and one hand pulls the skin downward in segments; other fingers grip the fruit to stabilize it. The peeled sections curl back, edges frayed, the pale cream flesh barely exposed where skin has separated. The person alternates grip and angle as they continue peeling.
peeling_banana.finished_description: End state: banana fully peeled; fruit exposed, curved cylindrical shape about 15–20 cm long; skin peeled away in strips, discarded; flesh pale creamy yellow, moist, soft, and slightly glossy; surface may show minor brown specks if ripe; stem end clean and flat where skin was removed. The person may be holding or about to eat it, slice it, mash it, or add it to cereal, yogurt, or a recipe.

peeling_potato.progress_description: Initially a potato is oval to round, 5–8 cm long, with brown skin and eye-like sprouts. In progress, skin is removed in ribbons, patches of bare pale flesh appear, and edges are irregular where skin remains. The surface shows a contrast between rough, dry skin and slick, moist flesh. The person holds a peeler or knife, rotates the potato, and applies steady pressure to lift skin in strips.
peeling_potato.finished_description: End state: a skinless potato, shape oblong to rounded, about original size minus trimmed edges; surface smooth, pale ivory to light yellow, slightly moist and glossy; eyes may be removed; any green areas trimmed away. After peeling, the person might rinse to remove starch, place in a bowl of water to prevent browning, pat dry, then dice, slice, or add to pot for cooking.

peeling_apple.progress_description: At the outset, the apple appears whole, round-to-oval, with intact skin (red/green/yellow) and a glossy surface. In progress, patches of skin are removed, revealing pale, crisp flesh; the color contrast between skin and flesh grows, and edges where skin curls away appear jagged or smooth. The tool (peeler or knife) is in contact, with hands guiding, rotating or pulling the fruit. Juices may bead on the surface; the shape remains similar but irregular as peeling continues.
peeling_apple.finished_description: End state: peeled apple with skin removed entirely, leaving a smooth, pale ivory to white flesh. Shape remains roughly spherical to oblate; diameter similar to original. Surface is crisp and juicy, lightly glossy, with tiny stringy remnants where skin came off. The core stays inside; no peel. If exposed to air, slight browning may begin. A person finished peeling might slice into wedges or chunks, remove the core, or place it on a board.

peeling_onion.progress_description: Start to mid-peel: the onion is roughly spherical to oval, with dry papery skin (brown, red, or white) over a moist interior. Partially peeled sections reveal smooth, translucent inner layers; skin peels away in curved strips. The person holds the onion, grips with fingers or a peeler/knife, twists and pulls, trims the root, and collects skin scraps nearby. The surface shows moisture and slight tearing where layers separate.
peeling_onion.finished_description: End state: the bulb is fully peeled of its papery outer skin and any dried root, leaving a clean, smooth, slightly glossy surface. The flesh beneath is crisp, firm, and moist; colors range white to pale yellow or purple; shape is rounded or oval; no loose skins; size remains roughly the same. If peeled to the core, inner rings are visible. The person finished peeling might wash hands and begin chopping or sautéing.

peeling_garlic.progress_description: In mid-peel garlic shows a bulb with its papery skin partly removed. The white, sometimes brown-speckled layer peels away in thin sheets, revealing a smooth, off-white clove beneath. Outer skin remains tacky and wrinkled where not yet peeled; the clove is rounded or tapered, its surface glistening with moisture. A person might press on a clove with thumb, pinch the skin between fingers, or slide a knife along the seam to loosen the peel.
peeling_garlic.finished_description: End state: peeled garlic cloves — plump, teardrop shapes, 0.5–2 cm long, ivory to pale tan, with a smooth, slightly glossy surface and all papery skins removed; root ends trimmed. Cloves vary in size but are clean and firm, moist to the touch. In the shot, the person is gathering the peeled cloves in a bowl, discarding skins, and likely readying them for chopping or mincing.

peeling_plantain.progress_description: Plantains are long, curved, 15–30 cm, with thick, waxy skin. Unripe fruit is green; as it ripens, yellow hues or a purple tinge may appear. Under the skin, the starchy flesh is firm and pale ivory. In mid-peel, skin splits along the length into broad strips, still partly adherent; exposed flesh remains not fully revealed. A hand holds the fruit while a knife or thumbnail lifts the seam and pries skin away in chunks.
peeling_plantain.finished_description: End state: a peeled plantain—an elongated, thick-skinned fruit about 15–25 cm long with husk removed, leaving the pale ivory to pale yellow flesh. The surface is smooth but can be slightly fibrous; firmness depends on ripeness. Unripe specimens stay starchy; ripe ones become softer and sweeter, with a touch of brown speckles on the flesh. After peeling, the person might be slicing it (coins or diagonals) for frying, boiling, or mashing, or washing and readying utensils.

peeling_egg.progress_description: Beginning or mid-peel, the egg shows partial shell removal with irregular edges. Visible egg white peeks where shell is removed; remaining shell fragments cling in small, jagged shards. A thin membrane and damp surface may reflect handling or water. The peeler’s fingers grip and lift sections, sometimes rolling the egg or sliding a fingernail under a seam, continuing to peel in incomplete stages.
peeling_egg.finished_description: End state: a fully peeled hard-boiled egg; shape is smooth, oval, about 4–5 cm long; shell absent; egg white opaque and firm, surface glossy and clean with no shell fragments; yolk (if cut) is firm, pale yellow; no cracks; slight membrane remnants may appear at the tips. After peeling, the person may rinse under cold water, pat dry, slice or halve, season, or place in a container for storage.

peeling_orange.progress_description: An in-progress peel shows a roughly spherical, hand-sized orange with rind; some areas still fully covered, others have exposed albedo where rind has been lifted. Curved strips of peel curl away, while untouched sections stay tight. The fruit remains firm and dimpled; pith may glint where rind is removed. A hand grips the fruit, slips a thumbnail or knife under the rind, and peels in curved, twisting motions, sometimes rotating the fruit to loosen sections.
peeling_orange.finished_description: End state: A fully peeled orange with its bright orange flesh exposed. The rind is removed, revealing plump, juice-filled segments held together by thin translucent membranes; the fruit is roughly spherical and moist, with minimal white pith possibly clinging to a few segments. The person is typically about to eat, cut into segments, place it on a plate, or discard the rind.

peeling_ginger.progress_description: During peeling, the ginger remains knobby and irregular, with tan papery skin that’s thin and sometimes flaky. The outer layer is partially stripped in brown ribbons, and patches of flesh may be visible where skin has begun to lift. The texture is fibrous and slightly dry, with a little moisture on the surface. A peeler or knife trims skin in short strokes while fingers guide the curved root, skin curling or flaking off in progress.
peeling_ginger.finished_description: End state: peeled ginger root with papery brown skin removed, revealing smooth, pale yellow to light tan flesh. Surface is moist, slightly glossy; fibrous texture visible but no skin. Irregular, knobby shape remains, variable size depending on piece. If peeled completely and ready, the person may begin slicing, mincing, grating, or adding the root to a bowl or pan, often patting dry or rinsing briefly.

peeling_carrot.progress_description: Start or intermediate peeling states show a fresh carrot with orange skin, tapering ends, and visible root hairs; dirt specks cling near the crown. As peeler glides, skin is shaved in thin curls or strips, exposing lighter orange flesh in patches. The surface becomes uneven: some segments still rough with skin, others smooth where peeled. The carrot remains firm and moist; blade angle is shallow, fingers steady, motion along the length, sometimes rotating the carrot.
peeling_carrot.finished_description: End state: a peeled carrot with its brownish skin removed, bright orange flesh exposed. Surface is smooth, glossy, with the ends trimmed flat. The carrot remains cylindrical and tapering, most of its length intact; uniform diameter, minimal blemishes, no rough patches. Flesh remains firm and crisp, moist but not wet. After peeling, the person may rinse and pat dry, then slice into sticks or coins, or transfer to a bowl or bag for cooking or storage.

peeling_cucumber.progress_description: An oblong cucumber with a firm, smooth surface and glossy green rind, often with lighter or darker banding. In progress, peel appears in thin, curling strips or ribbons; patches of unpeeled skin remain, producing a variegated green pattern. The person holds a peeler at a shallow angle, rotates the fruit, and applies steady pressure as the blade glides just under the skin; moisture beads on the surface. Grip is steady, non-slip.
peeling_cucumber.finished_description: End state: The cucumber is skinless and uniform in shape, a smooth cylindrical tube roughly the length of the original fruit; exterior skin removed, interior flesh pale green to light green, moist, crisp, and slightly translucent; ends trimmed, no blemishes or seeds exposed. The person may be slicing into rounds or sticks, placing it in a bowl or on a cutting board, or discarding the peels.

peeling_lemon.progress_description: During peeling, the lemon is a compact sphere with bright yellow rind, some rind still attached. Peel curls away in thin ribbons or chunky strips, revealing pale pith in spots. The surface may be slick with juice and shows grip marks. A hand uses a peeler or fingers, applying gentle traction, twisting or pulling rind in sections. The progress is irregular along the rind.
peeling_lemon.finished_description: End state: a fully peeled lemon, rind and pith removed, with the bright yellow flesh exposed. The fruit is small to medium, oval, about 3–6 cm, and the surface is smooth and juicy, with translucent segment membranes visible. The lemon feels firm but yielding. The person finished peeling is likely to juice it, slice into rounds or wedges, or zest the peel.

peeling_tomato.progress_description: Start and intermediate states: a round tomato, 2–6 cm, with smooth, taut skin—red, green, or yellow by ripeness. It’s held in hand or on a surface, glossy and moist. In progress, a thin skin strip lifts and curls at the edge; broader patches may be peeled, revealing a pale, matte underlayer. The worker uses a peeler or knife, rotating the tomato and guiding the blade along its curve.
peeling_tomato.finished_description: End state: a skinless tomato with a smooth, glossy red surface; flesh intact, moderately firm and juicy; no papery skin; shape roughly round or oblong, size depending on variety; moisture present; trimmed stem end may be present; interior seed cavity visible if split. After peeling, the person typically dices or chops it, slices it for a salad, or transfers the peeled fruit to a bowl or pot for cooking.

peeling_squash.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Start—whole squash, round/oval, firm rind, about 6–20 cm long; color varies by cultivar (green-striped, orange, yellow). In-progress—skin partially peeled in patches or ribbons; exposed pale flesh contrasts with remaining rind; edges uneven or clean; some damp shavings on the board. Action—the person holds a knife or peeler and runs it along the surface, rotating the squash to expose more skin.
peeling_squash.finished_description: End state: all skin removed from the squash piece; the flesh is exposed, smooth, and uniformly colored by cultivar. The piece’s overall shape mirrors the original and remains roughly the same size, though trimmed ends may shorten it. Flesh color ranges from pale (zucchini, some summer squash) to orange (butternut). Texture is firm and ready to cut. Next steps: dice or slice the flesh, scoop seeds, rinse, then roast, steam, or sauté.

peeling_avocado.progress_description: Start to mid-peel states: the avocado is oval-to-pear shaped, 5–10 cm long, with dark green to near-black skin. In progress, a sliver of skin is lifted or peeled back along one side, leaving patches of skin attached and exposed pale green flesh. The fruit remains firm to slightly yielding; the cut area may show a thin, slippery membrane. The person uses a paring knife or fingernails to lift, score, or peel, rotating the fruit as needed.
peeling_avocado.finished_description: End state: peeled avocado halves or scooped flesh, skin removed and pits extracted. Flesh is pale to bright green, very creamy and smooth, sometimes slightly fibrous near the pit if underripe. Exposed surfaces may brown slightly. The shape is pear-like/oval, about the fruit’s length, roughly 5–12 cm; thickness about 2–4 cm. After peeling, the person might scoop, mash, slice, dice, or plate with lemon juice.

peeling_mango.progress_description: At the start or during peeling, a mango is oval or oblong, about 6–12 cm long, with green to yellow skin. As peeling proceeds, skin comes off in uneven patches; the exposed flesh is pale yellow to orange and may look glossy or moist. The knife or peeler leaves grooves or jagged edges; juice may bead on the surface. A hand steadies the fruit while the other guides the blade, rotating to access edges.
peeling_mango.finished_description: End state: skin removed; a smooth, intact, elongated mango flesh (oval to oblong), about the fruit’s typical size. Flesh is bright yellow-orange, glossy and moist, sometimes with a pink/red blush. The surface is uniform in color with slight fibrous specks near the pit. A central seed cavity remains inside but is not exposed. The mango is ready for slicing, dicing, or plating; the person may be slicing or arranging pieces.

peeling_eggplant.progress_description: Eggplant begins as an intact fruit: elongated oval, 15–20 cm long, 4–6 cm diameter; glossy deep purple skin with a green stem; firm to the touch. In progress, skin lifts in thin curling strips; patches reveal pale cream flesh beneath; surface may be slightly waxy and moist. One hand steadies the fruit on a board while the other uses a peeler or knife to pare along its length, rotating as needed.
peeling_eggplant.finished_description: End state: peeled eggplant presents a smooth, pale cream flesh, with all purple skin removed; the oblong fruit is intact, typically 5–8 inches long, 2–3 inches wide, firm yet yielding to pressure; surface is glossy and uniform, with tiny pale seeds visible if sliced. The person is likely slicing or dicing into rounds or cubes, salting or rinsing to remove moisture, and readying for cooking.

peeling_pumpkin.progress_description: States of peeling: the pumpkin bears bright orange rind with pronounced ridges; patches of skin are removed, exposing lighter orange flesh. In-progress areas show thin, curling strips and jagged edges where the blade has lifted the rind. The surface is mottled with intact skin adjacent to peeled patches. The person steadies the fruit, rotates it as the peeler or knife travels along the curve, shaving rind in irregular strips, collecting scraps.
peeling_pumpkin.finished_description: End state: skin fully removed; flesh exposed, clean and oval/rounded block, tapered ends, roughly the size of the original fruit; color light orange to pale cream; smooth, moist surface, slightly fibrous; seeds and stringy pulp removed; no skin scraps; exposed cut surfaces, sometimes dry edges. The person finished peeling may set the pumpkin aside, wipe hands, or slice or cube the flesh on a cutting board with a knife nearby.

peeling_shrimp.progress_description: Start/in-progress shrimp show curved bodies about 2–3 inches, translucent gray-blue shells with ridges; legs and a dark vein along the back are visible. As peeling continues, shell halves detach in patches; head and some segments cling to shells while portions of flesh become exposed, pale pinkish-white and glossy. The worker grips the shell with fingers or a small knife, tugs at segments, and keeps shrimp upright to continue, leaving a mix of shell and exposed meat.
peeling_shrimp.finished_description: End state: peeled shrimp are shell-free, usually deveined; tails may be left on or removed, depending on prep. The meat is plump and curved; sizes vary by shrimp. Raw peeled shrimp are translucent gray; cooked become opaque pink-white. Texture is firm yet tender. After peeling, the person might rinse, pat dry, season, and prepare to cook or chill in a bowl or tray.

peeling_pear.progress_description: In peeling, the pear remains whole but with a patchwork of skin intact and stripped areas. The shape and size span compact to elongated, with a glossy greenish-yellow or brownish skin in places and pale, creamy flesh showing where skin has been removed. Texture is firm yet slightly yielding near the exposed surface. The peeler or knife is in use, fingers guiding, twisting or rolling the fruit to follow the contours, creating thin strips or arcs.
peeling_pear.finished_description: End state: a skinless pear with pale, creamy flesh, smooth and moist, retaining a pear-like shape (tapered top, wider base). Size roughly unchanged; surface uniform and free of brown skin. Texture ranges from firm to juicy depending on ripeness. The person finished peeling might be slicing into wedges or sticks, dicing for a recipe, or placing the peeled fruit in a bowl (often with lemon to prevent browning).

peeling_beet.progress_description: Beet starts as a round to oval, fist-sized root with dark red-purple skin and dirt. In progress, patches of thin, papery skin remain while bright magenta flesh begins to show beneath. The surface is firm and slightly glossy, with natural root ends and shallow grooves. The worker stabilizes the beet with one hand and uses a peeler or knife with the other, peeling away skin in strips or patches as it yields to the blade.
peeling_beet.finished_description: End state of peeling beet: a smooth, skinless root, round to oval, 2–4 inches in diameter, with bright reddish-purple flesh exposed. The surface is firm, slightly moist, and glossy; any dirt removed and ends trimmed. Optional greens kept or discarded. After peeling, the person is likely rinsing the beet, trimming excess, and cutting into wedges or cubes, grating, or placing in a roasting dish for cooking.

peeling_zucchini.progress_description: At the start, zucchini is firm, cylindrical, 6 to 8 inches long, with dark-green, striped skin. In progress, skin is shaved away in thin strips; the blade traces the curve, leaving curling ribbons and small shaved patches. Unpeeled areas glisten with glossy green skin, while peeled patches reveal pale, creamy flesh beneath. The handler grips near the end, rotates the vegetable, and maintains light, even pressure, keeping the blade shallow and moving steadily along the skin.
peeling_zucchini.finished_description: End state: Zucchini skin fully removed; the surface is smooth, pale green to ivory flesh, with a cylindrical shape and even diameter; the ends may be cleanly trimmed. The texture is firm, crisp, and moist; color uniform, no remaining peel. The peeled piece may be held, weighed, or placed in a bowl, then sliced, diced, julienned, or otherwise prepped for cooking.

peeling_prawn.progress_description: At start or in-progress states, prawns remain largely enclosed in shells: curved bodies, head and tail present, size variable from small to medium. Shell color is gray-blue and translucent; exposed flesh where shell is removed is pale pinkish, moist, and glistening. Some segments still show shell outlines; veins may be visible along the back. The person grips the shrimp, tugs at a shell segment, and peels while rinsing or readying for deveining.
peeling_prawn.finished_description: End state: peeled prawns with shells and often heads removed; tails may be left on for presentation or fully removed. Shape: slender, curved bodies about the prawn’s length; size varies by specimen. Color/texture: raw peeled meat is translucent gray-white, moist and firm; if deveined, the dark vein is gone. After peeling, the person might rinse, pat dry, then batch or marinate the prawns, or place them in a dish for cooking.

peeling_pepper.progress_description: Start: whole pepper, glossy skin, vibrant color (green/red/yellow), firm, with stem. In progress: patches of skin peeled away in strips or irregular patches, exposing the lighter inner flesh; edges jagged or curved; seeds/white pith may peek from the core; some moisture on surface; lobed silhouette remains. The person peeling grips the pepper, using a knife or peeler to score, pry, or lift skin, rotating the pepper as peeling continues.
peeling_pepper.finished_description: End state: peeled bell peppers with skin, seeds, and white pith removed. Shapes include halves, strips, or cubes; sizes vary with cuts. The surface is smooth, glossy, and vibrant in color (red, green, yellow, orange); flesh is firm yet tender, not wrinkled. The inner cavity is clean. The person finishing might rinse and pat dry, then slice, dice, or sauté, roast, or bag for storage.

peeling_shallot.progress_description: During peeling, the shallot bulb shows a papery outer skin partially removed: tan-brown or purple-tinted, with loose flakes clinging to the surface. The bulb remains whole, with the root end and crown often still attached. Strips or chunks of skin may flake away in ragged, curling pieces; some pale, moist inner flesh may be visible where skins lift. The person uses fingers or a knife, pinching, tearing, or slicing off the cap as skin comes away.
peeling_shallot.finished_description: End state: peeled shallots are globose bulbs with all papery skin removed, root and stem ends trimmed, exposing smooth, firm flesh. Color ranges from ivory to pale pink or yellow depending on variety; inner cloves are creamy white. Surface is moist, not sticky; size mirrors the bulb, typically small to medium. Once peeled, the person is likely chopping, slicing, or dicing them, or placing peeled bulbs in a bowl for cooking, storage, or rinsing.

peeling_peach.progress_description: Peach in early to mid-peel shows a round, 6–9 cm fruit with fuzzy skin partially loosened or curling at edge. Skin color is yellow-orange with a red blush; a thin strip or flap may peel away, leaving pale yellow, dewy flesh exposed. The surface near the peel is slick with juice. The person holds the fruit in one hand and uses a peeler or knife, drawing or shaving a strip and rotating the fruit to continue.
peeling_peach.finished_description: End state: a skinless peach, whole or halved, with smooth, moist, bright orange flesh exposed where skin has been removed. Size similar to original, about 2–3 inches in length; surface free of skin, faint fibrous lines, minimal bruising. If halved and pitted, the central cavity is exposed with lighter flesh. After peeling, the person may slice, dice, wedge, pit, or eat the fruit.

peeling_pineapple.progress_description: Start/intermediate state: A stout oval fruit with rough brown skin and a green crown. It's about fist-sized to larger, with hexagonal patterning and some moisture sheen. In progress, knife work strips away rind in curved patches; remaining rind shows partial yellow flesh and raised eyes. The surface is a mix of peeled and unpeeled areas; some eyes may be tool-cut. The person is rotating the fruit, slicing off skin, and paring around the crown and sides.
peeling_pineapple.finished_description: End state: a smooth, skinless pineapple with its crown and base trimmed. The exposed flesh is bright golden-yellow, uniform in color, with the eyes removed. The fruit’s shape is roughly cylindrical; the core may be visible or removed. Texture is moist and fibrous but tender. The person may be slicing into rounds or spears, dicing, or transferring the peeled fruit to a container.

peeling_kiwi.progress_description: An oval, hand-sized kiwi with brown, fuzzy skin shows partial peeling: a patch or strip of skin removed, exposing bright green flesh beneath. The remaining skin forms a curved border around the exposed area; the boundary is irregular, with some skin flakes and moisture on the surface. The person holds a knife or peeler, performing a side-to-side or circular motion, lifting skin in thin, curling strips while the fruit remains otherwise intact.
peeling_kiwi.finished_description: End state: A fully peeled kiwifruit is an oblong, finger-shaped berry about 4–9 cm long and 2–3 cm wide, with the brown fuzzy skin removed to reveal bright green flesh (or yellow flesh in gold kiwis) and a pale white core. The surface is smooth, juicy, and crisp, with tiny black seeds in a ring. After peeling, the person might slice into rounds or wedges, dice for a fruit salad, or eat it directly.

browning_onion.progress_description: During browning, onion pieces in a hot pan sweat: slices or dice become translucent, glossy, and slightly reduced in size. They show pale yellow to light amber edges, with softened, yielding texture. Steam and sizzle accompany the oil sheen; moisture fades as pieces separate and curl. The cook stirs, spreads pieces evenly, adjusts heat, possibly adds oil or salt, and uses the pan to move onions to prevent sticking and encourage uniform color change.
browning_onion.finished_description: End state of browned onions: they’re soft, flattened, and reduced, with color ranging from light golden to deep amber or chestnut; edges may be darker, center translucent and jammy; size has shrunk as moisture evaporates; texture is tender and slightly sticky, with a sweet, nutty aroma. A finished cook might deglaze the pan, scrape up fond, and incorporate the onions into sauces, gravies, soups, or fillings, or remove from heat to finish cooking elsewhere.

browning_chicken.progress_description: Start/intermediate: pieces are pale, slightly translucent at contact; surface is moist. As browning begins, edges turn light tan; parts of the surface dry and a faint crust forms. Small bubbles and sizzle indicate moisture leaving; fat may render at the edges. Color is patchy and uneven, with no uniform brown yet. The cook is watching the pan, adjusting heat, and turning pieces with tongs to maintain contact and even progression.
browning_chicken.finished_description: End state: chicken surfaces display a golden-to-amber crust, crisp exterior, slight curling, and even browning. Shape mostly intact with modest shrinkage from moisture loss. Interior turns opaque white with clear juices; no pink near bone. A well-browned piece feels firm with a crisp surface. After browning, the cook might reduce heat, flip again, and finish in a sauce or oven to reach 165°F internal temperature.

browning_garlic.progress_description: Start or mid browning garlic: sliced or minced pieces become translucent to pale yellow, with rims turning light amber. They soften, glisten in oil, and may curl or puff slightly; texture remains tender, not yet crisp. In progress, they hiss gently as moisture evaporates. The cook stirs or moves pieces for even contact, and nudges heat so edges brown gradually while centers stay lighter.
browning_garlic.finished_description: End state: garlic slices or minced bits have turned golden to amber-brown, with edges crisply curled; centers are pale but cooked through. The surface is glossy from oil and dry where most color occurred. Aroma is nutty-sweet and toasty. Texture ranges from crisp around the edges to tender in the center for slices or soft if minced. The cook finishes by removing from heat, possibly reserving, deglazing, or folding into a sauce before plating.

browning_meat.progress_description: In-progress browning shows meat pieces that have begun to sizzle. Surfaces shift from pale pink to pale tan, with emerging brown edges; the center may still look pink or raw. Fat renders, leaving a glossy, translucent sheen. The surface develops a faint crust, and small sear lines appear. Juices bubble and steam, causing minor curling or shrinking. The cook might pat dry, preheat the pan, place pieces in a single layer, and turn them for contact.
browning_meat.finished_description: End state: exterior deep brown crust from Maillard reaction; uniform surface color; edges crisp; surface drier and slightly tacky; shape largely unchanged; meat has shrunk slightly from fat rendering. Interior color depends on cut (steak may be medium-rare pink, chicken opaque white). Juices are less visible. Post-browning actions: rest the meat, deglaze the pan, and start sauce or transfer to a rack.

browning_beef.progress_description: In the early to mid browning stage, beef surfaces show uneven patches of pink to red centers with developing tan edges. The exterior begins to sear, forming a light crust where Maillard reactions occur; fat renders and beads of oil or juices shimmer on the surface. Meat contracts and shrinks slightly; the surface firms a touch as searing continues. Pieces may curl at the edges. A spatula flips to expose new faces, continuing the browning process.
browning_beef.finished_description: End state: beef surfaces develop a deep brown Maillard crust; color ranges from deep brown to caramelized at edges; moisture largely evaporated; fat rendered; texture firm with a crusty exterior and, in chunks, shrinkage from cooking. Ground beef is uniformly browned with no pink; slices are seared on outside. The pan will have fond. Next steps: deglaze the pan and start a sauce, or add aromatics and simmer.

browning_sausage.progress_description: In the start, sausage pieces are plump and pink with a slick fat surface. As they heat, color shifts to light gray-brown; fat renders into shiny droplets; edges begin to curl and surface moisture beads. Small bubbles form and steam rises. The cook may be turning and separating pieces, slicing crumbles, or pressing to encourage contact and redistribute heat to the still in-progress surface.
browning_sausage.finished_description: End state: Exterior evenly browned with a crisp, caramelized crust; color ranges from golden to mahogany; surface may glisten with rendered fat; sausage shrinks slightly; exterior is firm while interior becomes opaque and fully cooked (no pink) with juices sealed. The cook is likely flipping to ensure even sear and then removing from heat to finish cooking through or resting (often to a sauce or plate).

browning_butter.progress_description: Start or early stage: solid butter blocks in a wide pan melt into a pale gold liquid; the surface foams with small bubbles while a pool forms. Milk solids begin to separate and sink; tiny specks swirl as the mixture thickens slightly. In progress, the cook tilts and swirls the pan, keeps heat gentle, and uses a spatula to distribute heat and monitor color, without letting the solids scorch.
browning_butter.finished_description: End state: a smooth, pourable golden-to-deep-amber liquid with browned milk solids settled or lightly suspended. The surface gleams; a nutty aroma is present. A few dark specks may cling to the bottom. It may look slightly viscous as it cools. When done, the cook typically removes it from heat, pours into a container or pan, and uses it to finish a sauce, drizzle vegetables, or fold into batter.

browning_crust.progress_description: Start/intermediate browning crust begins pale cream to light tan, with a slightly tacky surface and tiny steam-blistered spots. As it progresses, color patches deepen, edges crisp while centers stay pliable, and the surface may crackle in irregular, reticulated patterns. Sugars caramelize faintly and aromas intensify. The baker may rotate, adjust heat, baste with fat or water, or lift to check progress.
browning_crust.finished_description: End state: a uniform golden to deep amber crust, crisp and dry to the touch, with crackled or blistered surface. Edges are crisp and slightly curled; surface may be matte or subtly glossy. Shape follows the item (round, loaf, or elongated); size matches footprint, with expanded volume from baking. Color reflects bake level; no wet dough remains. The person is removing the item from the oven onto a rack to cool, then slicing or serving.

browning_bacon.progress_description: In-progress bacon browning shows strips in a hot pan with sizzling fat. Meat shifts from pinkish-red to pale tan as fat renders; edges curl and buckle. The surface becomes mottled with translucent, oil-dotted patches; bubbles rise as moisture escapes. Strips shrink slightly and lie unevenly. The cook uses tongs to flip, reposition, and adjust heat, watching color changes and moisture release as browning progresses.
browning_bacon.finished_description: End state: Bacon is deep golden to dark brown, crisp and curling at the edges. The fat is mostly rendered, leaving a dry, crackly surface with a light oily sheen. Strips shrink slightly yet keep their shape; no pink remains in the meat. Texture is firm and brittle, with a smoky, savory aroma. The cook is removing it from heat, transferring to paper towels to drain, and plating.

browning_pork.progress_description: At the start or during browning, pork pieces (slices or chunks) of varying sizes lie in hot fat; surfaces begin pale brown to tan with pinkish or grayish centers still visible. Fat glistens and renders; moisture sizzles, producing bubbles. The crust remains soft in places; initial sear lines form; edges may curl. The cook keeps pieces moving, rotating, flipping, nudging them for contact, and adjusting heat to continue browning.
browning_pork.finished_description: End state: the pork has developed a golden-brown to dark bronze crust via Maillard browning; surface is dry with a crisp edge; the piece has shrunk slightly from rendering fat but retains its shape; exterior is firm to the touch; interior color varies with doneness, from pale pink to gray; most moisture is reduced. After browning, the cook may deglaze, finish in the oven or sauce, rest, or slice.

browning_meatball.progress_description: Early-stage meatballs are roughly spherical, about 1–2 inches in diameter, with smooth, intact surfaces and a pale pinkish-gray color. As browning begins, the exterior develops light tan or gold patches; surface becomes slightly drier and less shiny; juices may begin to bead. Edges may lift or crack, and the interior remains softer and warmer pink. The cook often dots with spatula, turns them, and adjusts heat to promote even color without overcooking.
browning_meatball.finished_description: End state: spherical, evenly browned crust ranging from golden to dark brown, crisp outer surface with Maillard caramelization; exterior shows slight glaze from fat; size nearly the same or marginally smaller due to moisture loss; interior remains moist and pale to light brown if not fully cooked; surface texture firm but not rubbery. Post-browning actions: the person uses tongs to flip or remove meatballs, possibly transferring to sauce or oven to finish cooking.

browning_mushroom.progress_description: Start/intermediate browning: Mushrooms are pale white to cream, plump, caps smooth. As browning begins, surfaces become translucent and slightly glossy as moisture evaporates; edges may curl inward. Patches of pale beige appear where heat is concentrated; cap size remains similar or slightly reduced as they soften. Texture shifts from firm to tender. The cook is sautéing or pan-searing, stirring or spreading the mushrooms in a hot pan with oil or butter to encourage contact.
browning_mushroom.finished_description: End state: sliced mushrooms have shrunk and softened; caps may curl. Color ranges from golden to deep caramel brown with caramelized edges. Exterior may be slightly crisp; interior tender to chewy. Most moisture is evaporated, with a light gloss from fat. The cook is likely off heat, removing them from the pan, deglazing, or tossing into a dish, then plating or tasting.

browning_tofu.progress_description: In the pan, tofu pieces (cubes or slabs) lie in a single layer, edges starting to sear and pockets of moisture hiss as small sizzles. Surfaces show a mix of pale ivory with patchy tan to light gold; some areas remain glossy or damp while others begin to dry and firm. Shrinkage is gradual; edges may lift or curl. The cook is pressing, flipping, and maintaining contact for uneven browning to develop.
browning_tofu.finished_description: End state: tofu cubes (1–2 cm) or slabs have a uniform golden to deep brown crust on all exposed faces, with the exterior crisp and slightly caramelized while the interior remains tender. Surface shows a slight sheen and occasional darker edges; minor shrinkage from moisture loss. Color ranges from light amber to dark gold; texture transitions from soft to crisp. The cook may be tossing the cubes in a skillet, draining, or plating with sauce.

browning_turkey.progress_description: Start and in-progress states: turkey pieces are irregular in shape, with slight shrinkage and pockets of moisture. They begin pale pink with translucent surfaces; as browning advances, areas darken to light tan and blotchy patches appear. Moisture beads fade; fat renders and pools; skin tightens while edges curl and crisp unevenly. In the pan you’ll hear sizzle and see steam; the cook flips, rearranges, and baste, adjusting heat for even contact.
browning_turkey.finished_description: End state: surface uniformly golden to amber brown with Maillard crust; edges crisp; exterior dry with slight gloss from rendered fat; sear marks present but even; interior white-to-pale, fully heated; shape largely intact with slight shrink due to cooking; internal temp ~165°F. The cook may rest the turkey, deglaze for fond, or move it to the oven to finish roasting, then slice or plate.

browning_steak.progress_description: Start: a thick steak on a hot pan, surface beads of moisture, center looks red, fat glossy. Early in-progress: sizzle starts; first pin-point crust along contact area; edges begin to curl; juices surface; fat continues to render. Mid-progress: irregular patches of crisping form, sear lines emerge, pan crackles louder; meat firms slightly as moisture evaporates; shape remains roughly the same while the texture darkens at the contact zone.
browning_steak.finished_description: End state of browning steak: a well-formed, dark brown to golden crust with crisp, slightly blistered surface; edges may be charred. Exterior is firm to the touch; fat rendered and juices visible as a light sheen. The steak has shrunk slightly in width and thickness. Interior doneness varies (rare to medium) depending on finish. After browning, the cook often moves it to oven to finish, then rests before slicing.

browning_potato.progress_description: Potato pieces (sticks, wedges, or cubes) of even thickness sit in hot oil or a skillet. Surface moisture gleams; edges begin to tan from pale ivory toward light amber while centers stay pale and opaque. The starch-softens at the exterior, giving a slight tender bite. Bubbling oil and sizzles accompany occasional flips, shifts, and spacing adjustments to expose all sides evenly.
browning_potato.finished_description: End state: potato pieces are uniformly browned on all exposed faces, with a crisp, dry exterior and a tender, fluffy interior. They retain their shape but may shrink slightly and show curling edges; color ranges from warm gold to deep amber. Texture is a crackly crust with a moist center; surface may be lightly blistered. The cook is removing from heat, draining on paper towels, and plating or tossing with salt.

browning_bread.progress_description: Start/intermediate states of browning bread: Shape remains rectangular with rounded corners; size unchanged; surface transitions from pale, moist, slightly glossy to a pale gold. Color variation appears as spots of light tan and rising crust at edges; texture shifts from tender and chewy to drying, with a thin crust starting to form along rims. Steam escapes; aroma intensifies. The person may press, lower or adjust the toaster, flip slices, or lift to inspect.
browning_bread.finished_description: End state: a loaf with a uniform golden-brown crust, sometimes amber to deep tan, crisp and crackly to touch; surface with slight sheen or flour dusting; overall shape domed with rise, edges lightly pulled away from pan; crust provides audible crackle when broken; interior crumb fully set, moist but not gummy, with small, air pockets. The baker is typically removing from the oven, cooling on a rack, and may brush with butter or slice for serving.

browning_vegetable.progress_description: Early browning shows pieces starting to color at surfaces: edges become brown or tan, centers remain pale; moisture evaporates and oil shimmers. Shapes may flatten or curl; textures range from glossy to translucent, with small caramelized specks forming. In-progress browning often displays uneven color, with rims darker than centers and edges developing a crisp rim while interiors stay soft. The cook is sautéing or tossing in a pan, watching color change and moving pieces as needed.
browning_vegetable.finished_description: End state: vegetables exhibit golden-brown to deep caramelized surfaces, with edges crisp and centers tender; color ranges from light amber to mahogany; moisture reduced, slight gloss, and a faint fond on the pan. Size may shrink modestly. Aroma is nutty-sweet. The cook may be finishing by removing from heat, deglazing, or transferring to a plate/dish, possibly tossing into another dish or serving; they might taste, drain excess liquid, or wipe the pan.

browning_sugar.progress_description: In start/intermediate browning, sugar exists as dissolving granules or a still-wet syrup. Edges remain distinct while the center grows glossy and cohesive. Color shifts from clear or pale straw to light amber as water cooks away; syrup thickens and becomes more viscous. Tiny bubbles break the surface; pan walls develop a thin film. Crystalline pockets may cluster at the bottom. The cook heats gently, swirls or stirs, and monitors color and consistency to avoid overheating.
browning_sugar.finished_description: End state: melted, no grains; color ranges from pale amber to deep copper; glossy, viscous, pourable syrup with a slight elastic pull. It coats the spoon in a thin film and will harden into a candy shell when cooled. The cook might immediately remove from heat and whisk in butter or cream for caramel sauce, or pour onto parchment to set, or use it to glaze a dessert.

browning_apple.progress_description: Start/intermediate browning is seen first on freshly cut surfaces. Slices or wedges show pale, white flesh with a brief translucent sheen. Edges develop a faint tan to light brown halo, often irregular and localized rather than uniform. Brown patches may appear as specks or streaks along the incision. The texture remains firm and moist, with no full color change yet. The person is slicing, dicing, or exposing the cut surfaces to air, possibly stirring or tossing.
browning_apple.finished_description: End state depends on method. Oxidation alone: exposed surfaces turn brown (tan to dark); interior remains pale; shape largely intact; texture firm with possible slight crispness. Cooking (sauté/bake): surface deep amber to brown; flesh soft to tender or mushy; volume reduced; aroma sweet. When browning is done, color and texture match the target (caramelized or oxidized). The person may be slicing, seasoning, plating, tasting, or serving the apples (in a dish, salad, or dessert).

browning_banana.progress_description: At the outset, the banana is yellow, curved, with smooth skin. As browning begins, small brown speckles appear on the peel and flesh near the surface, and the surface softens slightly. Flesh may become creamy and translucent around the speckles; color shifts from pale white-yellow to light tan in patches. The fruit may feel less rigid near affected areas; size unchanged. The person is slicing, mashing, or letting air contact cut surfaces to proceed.
browning_banana.finished_description: End state: banana whose peel is heavily speckled to dark brown/black, skin loose and slipping; the fruit inside is fully softened to a creamy, mashed consistency with tan to dark brown flecks; aroma sweet banana. Size remains elongated but may appear squashed from bruising; surface may show minor bruises and splits. A finished browning banana is typically prepared for mashing or folding into batter, smoothies, or baking; the person is mashing, mixing, or peeling to use.

slicing_onion.progress_description: Start and intermediate onion states include a whole onion with papery skin and intact root; partially peeled to reveal pale, layered flesh; outer layers loosened and skin torn. As slicing begins, the knife engages the onion, creating partial vertical or horizontal cuts; the hand keeps fingers tucked in a claw grip; surface is moist and glossy; partial rings or strips form, edges are uneven, and pieces vary in size, not yet fully separated.
slicing_onion.finished_description: End state: evenly cut onion slices laid out or in a pile. Shapes: rings or short half-moon pieces; thickness about 2–5 mm. Color: white to pale yellow with translucent edges; texture crisp and moist; cut surfaces smooth; papery skin removed; root end trimmed. The person might be sautéing, adding to a pan, transferring to a bowl, or rinsing/wiping the knife and board.

slicing_tomato.progress_description: Start or in-progress states: a whole tomato, roughly 2 inches in diameter, on a cutting board, red skin, green stem cap attached. In mid-cut, the blade has pierced flesh, producing shallow incisions or partial rounds; the tomato remains attached at the stem, not yet separated. Juice beads on the surface. Seeds visible behind tissue. The handler steadies the fruit with one hand, guides the knife, rotating for new cuts.
slicing_tomato.finished_description: End state: evenly sliced tomato pieces—rounds or wedges—uniform thickness (roughly 3–6 mm), skin intact, bright red exterior with pale interior, visible seeds, and glistening moisture; edges clean, no mush. The person may be Collecting slices, transferring them to a bowl or plate, patting them dry, or starting to add them to a salad, pan, or dish.

slicing_apple.progress_description:
- Start: a medium-sized, round apple on a cutting board, whole and glossy—skin red/green/yellow, stem intact.
- Intermediate: knife tip enters the fruit; blade angled ~30–45°, shallow cut through skin; pale, crisp flesh shown; juice beads on surface; apple wobbles slightly as the other hand steadies it. The person is guiding the knife, applying downward pressure and gently sawing or levering along a curve, with fingers clear of the blade.
slicing_apple.finished_description: End state: evenly cut apple pieces—uniform slices or wedges about 0.5–1 cm thick, with intact colored skins (red, green, or yellow) and pale, crisp interior; exposed flesh shows moisture and occasional browning if delayed. No core fragments; edges clean and straight or gently curved. The person is likely arranging slices on a plate, dicing them further, or placing them into a container for storage or cooking.

slicing_potato.progress_description: During the early or intermediate stage of slicing, the potato appears partially cut: some surfaces have exposed pale flesh; intact skin on others; slices that are uneven in thickness, with knife marks visible and edges rough or clean where cut; cross-sections show fibrous texture; the form remains mostly whole or with a few separated fragments yet still connected on one side; the knife is actively moving, hand guiding, on a cutting board; moisture beads on surface.
slicing_potato.finished_description: End state: a pile of evenly cut potato slices or sticks on a cutting board. Shapes are round coins, oblong wedges, or baton-like sticks; uniform thickness (roughly a few millimeters to a centimeter); skin on or peeled; interior pale white to creamy yellow; edges clean and straight; surface slightly moist with fine starch sheen. The person may be transferring slices to a bowl, rinsing/soaking to reduce browning, or patting them dry before frying or boiling.

slicing_mushroom.progress_description: At the start or during the process, a mushroom shows a cap and slender stem, colors from ivory to tan to brown, surface moist or dry. As slicing continues, you see cuts, radial or circular cross-sections, and varying thickness from fine slivers to thicker discs. Knife marks may be clean or ragged, flesh resisting or yielding. The cutter steadies the mushroom, angles the blade, and collects incomplete pieces on a cutting board, moving methodically with passes.
slicing_mushroom.finished_description: End state: evenly sliced mushrooms form uniform circular discs about 2–3 mm thick, white to pale tan on the outside with pale, crisp-to-slightly-spongy flesh inside. Edges are smooth; surfaces may show residual moisture; gills are not visible in cross-section. The person may be transferring slices to a pan for sautéing, to a bowl for mixing, or to an airtight container for storage.

slicing_garlic.progress_description: Early in slicing, a whole garlic bulb sits with papery skin intact; individual cloves appear ivory with a dry sheath. As cutting begins, the blade meets the clove, leaving a gap of uncut skin; the clove may be halved or quartered, revealing pale, moist flesh. Slices are uneven and partial, edges ridged, with some bits still connected by a thin skin. The knife shows motion; the hand stabilizes, guiding, not crushing.
slicing_garlic.finished_description: End state: uniform thin garlic slices (rounds or slivers), about 1–2 mm thick; white to pale yellow with translucent centers; moist, smooth surface and clean edges; arranged in a pile or spread on the cutting board. The person is likely about to sauté them in oil or butter, or transfer to a hot pan or pot to cook with the dish.

slicing_lemon.progress_description: A lemon sits on a cutting board with a blade entering the rind. The rind is bright yellow, glossy, with white pith visible where the cut begins; flesh shows pale, translucent segments just beneath. The knife creates shallow grooves; the lemon remains largely intact, with rind still enclosing the interior. Beads of juice cling to the surface. The hand stabilizes the fruit, fingers curled away from the blade, rotating the fruit to continue slicing.
slicing_lemon.finished_description: End state: evenly cut lemon pieces—round disks or crescent wedges—laid on the cutting surface. Exterior bright yellow rind; interior translucent pale-yellow pulp segmented by thin membranes; white pith around the edges. Pieces are moist and glossy, seeds visible or removed. Sizes vary with knife depth, typically 0.5–1.5 cm thick for rounds. The person may transfer slices to a plate or bowl, or move on to juicing or zesting.

slicing_banana.progress_description: Start: a whole, curved banana with yellow skin and brown freckles rests on a board. In progress: the knife has begun slicing, leaving shallow grooves or incomplete cross-sections. The pale cream flesh is exposed where peeled back or cut; skin may still cover. Slices vary in thickness; some rings are only partly separated, surface moist. The person steadies the fruit and guides the blade with measured downward strokes.
slicing_banana.finished_description: End state: The banana is peeled and cut into uniform crosswise slices (coins) about 5–8 mm thick, or neat diagonal pieces if angling the cut. Outer skin is yellow with brown speckles; inner flesh is pale cream, soft, moist, and creamy with clean knife edges. Surfaces may show slight browning if ripe. The person may be adding the slices to cereal/yogurt, a smoothie, fruit salad, or arranging them for dessert or freezing.

slicing_strawberry.progress_description: Start/intermediate: a whole strawberry with green calyx, bright red skin, smooth contour; mid-slice, the knife is in motion, leaving partial slits or wedges; the flesh near the blade is pale pink to white and moist; seeds along the skin remain visible; the fruit may wobble slightly under gentle pressure; the person’s fingers grip the berry lightly, knuckles angled, keeping the blade away from fingertips on a cutting board.
slicing_strawberry.finished_description: End state: neatly cut strawberry slices with uniform thickness. Cuts yield circular cross-sections or curved crescents, edges clean and not ragged. Exposed flesh pale pink to red, outer skin bright red; tiny yellow seeds and glossy moisture visible. Texture firm yet juicy; slices hold shape without tearing. After slicing, the person is likely arranging slices for a fruit salad or topping, transferring to a bowl, or dicing further for recipes.

slicing_cabbage.progress_description: A whole cabbage head with damp, pale-green outer leaves and an intact core sits on a cutting board. In progress, a knife sinks through the head; the blade creates thick wedge-like cross-sections and long ribbons or irregular chunks as leaves separate. Cut surfaces appear pale, compact, with concentric leaf rings visible. The non-dominant hand steadies the head while the dominant hand slices downward or in a rocking motion, pausing as pieces are cut but not finished.
slicing_cabbage.finished_description: End state: cabbage is uniformly cut into slender ribbons (julienne) or fine shreds; width typically 2–4 mm, length variable. Color pale green to white; texture crisp and damp; pieces evenly sized with minimal core bits; surface clean, no brown edges; moisture visible on cut surfaces. The person may be collecting the slices in a bowl, transferring to a pan for sautéing, or tossing with dressing/seasoning for slaw.

slicing_meat.progress_description: Start: a whole meat piece on a cutting board with intact shape, uniform exterior color, visible marbling. In progress: a shallow incision begins; blade at a slight angle; interior remains mostly concealed, surface glistening with juices. Partial slices emerge: thickness varies, edges jagged, fibers and fat strands exposed. The person stabilizes with one hand and guides the knife with the other, applying steady pressure and incremental passes as slicing continues.
slicing_meat.finished_description: End state: uniformly sized slices with straight, clean cut surfaces; consistent thickness; moist, slightly glossy surfaces; color ranges pinkish-red to brownish depending on meat; no torn fibers or jagged edges; evenly arranged or neatly stacked with no excess liquid. After slicing, the handler may transfer slices to a tray or container for packaging, wrap or label, wipe the knife and board, and return the meat to refrigeration or continue cooking prep.

slicing_zucchini.progress_description: State at start or mid-slicing: a whole zucchini on a cutting board, dark green skin with lighter ribbing, firm and cylindrical. As slicing begins, the blade is positioned against the skin; the zucchini may be stabilized by one hand while the other guides the knife in a straight or rocking motion. In-progress surfaces show a pale interior just starting to appear beneath the skin; cross-sections may be partially exposed, with the cut edge moist and fibrous.
slicing_zucchini.finished_description: End state: zucchini sliced into uniform discs (or half-moons) about 1/4 inch thick; skin dark green, flesh pale green to white; crisp, moist, with clean, straight edges and even cross-sections. The person may be stacking slices, transferring to a bowl or baking sheet, patting them dry, or proceeding to sauté, roast, steam, or mix into a dish.

slicing_chicken.progress_description: Starting state shows a raw chicken piece on a board, skin on or off. The knife’s blade is partially through or about to enter, creating a shallow groove. The surface is pale pink with white fat and a light sheen of moisture. Fiber strands separate under light pressure. Hands: dominant hand grips the knife with a pinch or claw, non-dominant hand steadies the piece. In-progress state shows uneven partial slices, thickness varies, edges still attached.
slicing_chicken.finished_description: End state: uniform slices with clean edges and consistent thickness (a few millimeters to about a centimeter). Color: pale pink to white for raw meat, with a slightly moist, matte surface; no bone or cartilage exposed. Texture should be firm and sliceable, not ragged or mushy. After slicing, the person might season or marinate, transfer to a pan or tray, or proceed to dicing or cooking.

slicing_mango.progress_description: Start: a mango with skin intact, green turning to yellow-orange, whole or partially peeled; flesh is unseen except for faint translucence near the skin.
