In progress: a knife enters the curved fruit, leaving shallow grooves; some skin is peeled, exposing bright orange flesh; juice beads form on the surface; the mango tilts as it’s rotated. The person stabilizes the fruit with one hand and guides the blade with measured strokes, reorienting as they go.
slicing_mango.finished_description: End state: mango flesh detached from the stone, peeled, cut into uniform pieces (wedges or cubes) about 1–2 cm thick, 3–5 cm long; vivid orange-yellow, glossy, juicy, and tender yet firm, with minimal fibrous strands and no rind. The surface is clean, slices lie neatly on a cutting board or in a bowl. The person may be scooping into a bowl, serving, adding to a fruit salad or smoothie, or washing the knife.

slicing_pepper.progress_description: Starting states: whole peppers (green, red, yellow, orange) on a cutting board; glossy, firm skin; sometimes halved or with seeds visible. In progress: the knife is mid-slice, flesh yielding, partial cuts creating uneven edges; pepper may tilt or rotate; membranes and moisture visible; regions vary in thickness; shapes range from partial wedges to rough slabs; grip and guiding hand stabilize the pepper while the other hand advances the knife.
slicing_pepper.finished_description: End state: a pile of neatly cut pepper pieces—rings (from crosswise slices), strips, dice, or wedges—uniform thickness (about 4–8 mm), with glossy, crisp flesh and moist interior. Colors match cultivar (green, red, yellow, orange); seeds and core largely removed; edges clean. On the board or in a bowl, ready for cooking or further prep. The person finished may be moving pieces to a pan or container, or cleaning up.

slicing_cake.progress_description: Start/in-progress states: A whole cake on a board (round or square) with pale, smooth icing and visible layers. As slicing begins, a knife makes clean vertical or angled cuts, creating partial wedges or straight segments. You see cut lines, frosting ridges, and crumbs along the blade. The cutter's hands apply steady, saw-like or press-and-pull motions; a few slices may be separated but still attached or only partially lifted.
slicing_cake.finished_description: End state: the cake is divided into evenly sized portions—triangle wedges on a circular cake or squares on a sheet—each with clean, sharp edges and a visible, uniform crumb interior in the cake color. Frosting remains intact on the outer surfaces, tops may show decor or smooth finish. Slices may sit on individual plates or be arranged back on a platter, with a knife or server set aside. The person is serving or lifting a slice.

slicing_shallot.progress_description: Start state: a whole shallot with papery brown-purple skin, intact root cap, and dry outer layers. As slicing proceeds, the skin loosens; the bulb reveals pale, slightly translucent flesh with purple veins. Incomplete cuts yield partial rings and uneven wedges, some slices still joined by internal membranes, edges ragged. The knife motions show downward presses and lift-and-slide, while the slicer peels more skin, trims the root end, and moves portions to the board, intermittently regrouping pieces.
slicing_shallot.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut shallot pieces, typically about 1–2 mm thick if sliced crosswise into rings, yielding pale purple–white, translucent slivers; alternatively, small 2–5 mm cubes or half-moon slices depending on method. Edges clean, surface smooth, no brown discoloration. Texture crisp-tender; aroma bright. The preparer is likely transferring the pile to a bowl or skillet, patting dry, or sautéing with oil.

slicing_egg.progress_description: Start or mid-slice states show an egg on the cutting surface or tilted. The egg’s oval shape and variable size, with white or brown shell, may display moisture sheen. The knife tip makes a shallow groove or crack; shell fragments cling to the blade. The interior looks translucent white in raw eggs or opaque in cooked ones as the cut progresses. The person steadies the knife, applies pressure, and may rotate the egg to widen the cut.
slicing_egg.finished_description: End state of slicing egg: a set of uniform discs, each slice roughly 2–4 mm thick, with smooth, straight edges and no shell fragments. For a hard-boiled egg, the exterior is white and opaque, the interior yolk is a centered pale yellow disk; color contrast is white-to-yellow. The slices hold their shape (firm yet tender) without yolk leakage. In video, the person may align, stack, season, or plate the slices for serving or garnish.

slicing_sausage.progress_description: Start or mid-slice frames show a roughly cylindrical sausage log on a cutting board: casing intact or peeled, with one end partially cut. A knife is mid-stroke or paused, bevel facing down; one hand steadies the log, the other guides the blade. Surfaces are glossy and moist; interior pink-red with white fat marbling. Partial cross-sections, uneven edges, and exposed interior indicate slicing in progress.
slicing_sausage.finished_description: End state: neatly sliced rounds (or lengthwise coins) of uniform thickness, with clean edges. Cross-sections show pink-reddish interior with visible fat flecks; outer casing may be present or removed. Slices look glossy and moist, often stacked, fanned, or lined on a cutting board, ready for cooking or plating. After slicing, the person might transfer slices to a pan, plate, or container, or wipe the board and knife.

slicing_watermelon.progress_description: In early- to mid-slicing, the watermelon is partly exposed: green rind, bright red crisp flesh with visible seeds; round cross-sections and partial wedges are forming. Knife marks traverse curved surfaces; the cut surfaces are moist and show varying thickness. A portion may be separated but still attached along a line. The cutter’s hands guide the blade, angle it, and push through the fruit on a cutting board; motion is ongoing.
slicing_watermelon.finished_description: End state: watermelon is cut into neat pieces, wedges or cubes, with rind trimmed and flesh exposed. Flesh is bright red or pink, crisp and juicy, with seeds mostly removed. Pieces on a cutting board or platter appear uniform in size; surfaces glisten with juice. The user, finished slicing, is likely transferring pieces to a serving dish, wiping the knife, discarding rind, or placing the tray in the fridge.

slicing_carrot.progress_description: Start/ intermediate states show a firm, elongated orange carrot with variable peel; some sections still whole, others bear shallow knife marks at partial depths. The cut face reveals glossy orange interior, sometimes lighter near the surface. The blade angle may be steep or shallow, leaving uneven bevels and tiny chips. Slivers may protrude; moisture glistens on fresh surfaces, and uncut segments remain alongside newly scored ones.
slicing_carrot.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut carrot pieces with clean, straight cuts. Shapes include rounds (coin-sized) or batons (matchstick-sized). Exterior bright orange; interior paler; crisp, firm texture with a slight moisture sheen and smooth, ragged-free edges. Pieces are evenly sized and either neatly aligned or lightly scattered on the cutting board. Next actions: transfer to a bowl or pan, then sauté, boil, bake, or add to a salad.

slicing_tofu.progress_description: Start: A white tofu block (rectangular prism), smooth, pale exterior, lightly moist surface; interior porous and spongy. In progress: partial cuts yield uneven slabs; some slices still attached along one plane; surface cut faces are pale, with visible knife marks; thickness varies, edges may be clean or jagged; the block may rotate on the board. The person stabilizes the block with one hand and slices with a knife, guiding with fingers well away from the blade.
slicing_tofu.finished_description: End state: uniform rectangular slices from a tofu block, about 0.5 cm (0.2 in) thick, roughly 4x2 inches each; pale ivory color; smooth surface with clean edges; firm yet springy, holds shape without crumbling; light moisture sheen, often patted dry. After slicing, they might stack or arrange slices, blot excess moisture, season or marinate, and start pan-searing, sautéing, or plating.

slicing_ginger.progress_description: At the start or mid-slice, ginger is often whole with skin on or partially peeled. The knife is mid-press, leaving a shallow groove or a partially separated wedge. Shaving varies in thickness; some pieces remain bulky while others are thinning. Flesh is pale yellow, fibrous and damp, with stringy strands; brown skin may be exposed or peeling. Edges appear jagged or uneven, and small shreds curl as slicing continues.
slicing_ginger.finished_description: End state: uniform ginger slices, about 2–3 mm thick, circular or oval discs with pale yellow flesh, clean outer edges, thin translucent rims, moist and slightly fibrous, with the peel removed. The person might be stacking the slices, transferring them to a bowl or pan, or moving on to mince, dice, or grate them for the recipe.

slicing_leek.progress_description: Start: whole leek, long white base with pale green stalks, dark green tips, clean skin, crisp, with a mild onion aroma. In progress: knife has made partial longitudinal and/or crosswise cuts; some rings and layers exposed, gaps between cuts, surface wet from moisture; the stalk lies on the board and is rotated or shifted to guide more cuts; thickness varies as work proceeds.
slicing_leek.finished_description: End state: trimmed, washed leeks cut into uniform 2–3 mm slices, forming rings or half-moon crescents; white to pale green, edges translucent, surface smooth with clean knife marks, no grit or brown spots; evenly sized and ready for cooking. The cook might now sauté or sweat them in oil or butter, or add to a pot for soup or stock.

slicing_beef.progress_description: Start/intermediate states show beef blocks or roasts on a cutting board with the grain visible. Interior is pink-red with pale marbling; surface is moist and slightly glossy. Partially sliced portions appear as uneven slabs, some thickness variations, edges rough or clean depending on blade. Slices may curl or separate as the blade advances. The cutter grips the knife, steadies the meat, and makes measured strokes, occasionally readjusting grip or rotating the chunk to expose fresh faces.
slicing_beef.finished_description: End state of slicing beef: uniform, parallel slices with clean, straight edges and consistent thickness (roughly 2 to 5 mm). Shape is rectangular/oval depending on cut; color is deep red for raw slices with visible marbling; surface is moist, texture smooth and firm. If cooked, exterior browns while interior remains pinkish. The person may be arranging slices on a tray, packaging, bagging, or transferring to a pan for cooking.

slicing_cucumber.progress_description: Start: a cucumber is whole, 15–20 cm long, dark-green skin, light-green flesh, crisp and moist. In progress: portions show shallow, partial cuts or scored lines; some slices are only partially formed and not yet separated; skin may be peeled or scored; cross-sections reveal pale interiors and seeds. The object remains cool and firm, with uneven thickness where the knife has passed. The slicer steadies cucumber with one hand, slides the knife with controlled pressure, pausing mid-stroke.
slicing_cucumber.finished_description: End state: neatly arranged cucumber slices—usually uniform rounds about 3–4 mm thick, though longwise cuts yield half-moons. The skin is dark green; the flesh pale green with a crisp, juicy, watery texture; seeds are small or centered. Edges are clean and glossy. If the slicer is finished, they’re scooped into a bowl or piled on the board, ready for salad, relish, or further dicing/sticks.

slicing_scallion.progress_description: Start or intermediate states: Whole scallion with trimmed root and a few green stalks; or peeled, partly cut stalk on a cutting board. In-progress slices show a two-tone stalk (white base, green tops) with knife marks and uneven cross-sections. Shown are thin or partial slivers, variable thickness, some sections intact, some cut through. The texture is crisp and moist; fibers may show. The person holds the knife, guides the blade, and pauses between cuts, fingers clear.
slicing_scallion.finished_description: End state: scallion is sliced into uniform pieces, typically round disks a few millimeters thick (or fine julienne if that cut was used), with white bases and green tops. Color transitions from crisp white to bright green. Pieces are crisp, fresh, lightly glossy, with clean edges. They may be gathered in a bowl or spread on a dish. A cook might garnish, sauté briefly, or fold them into a salad or soup.

slicing_eggplant.progress_description: Starting state shows a whole or halved eggplant: glossy deep purple skin, firm, slightly spongy body; stem end intact. As slicing progresses, the knife creates partial cuts: thin or thick blade marks, uneven spacing, and exposed pale cream flesh with a moist sheen. Rounds or slabs remain partially connected to the core; some sections stay attached. The user grips the knife, steadies the vegetable, and advances the blade.
slicing_eggplant.finished_description: End state: eggplant is cut into uniform discs (or batons, depending on cut) about 0.25–0.5 inch thick; skin glossy deep purple, flesh pale ivory with small seeds; exterior firm, interior tender; surface lightly bruised but intact; juices may bead. Arrangement typically in neat rows or a single layer on a board. The person may be salting to remove bitterness, patting dry, or proceeding to dredge, oil, and roast or sauté.

slicing_avocado.progress_description: At the start: whole avocado or a halved fruit with dark, bumpy skin and pale-green flesh. In progress: a knife has begun a lengthwise or crosswise cut; the pit may still be present or just removed. The exposed flesh is bright green and creamy, with edges pale or slightly brown from oxidation; cuts are shallow, producing irregular wedges or partial slices still attached to the skin. The person is guiding the blade and rotating the fruit.
slicing_avocado.finished_description: End state: avocado halves with the pit removed; flesh pale green-to-yellow, creamy and smooth. Slices are clean-cut wedges or uniform cubes, with crisp, light-colored edges and minimal browning. Skin remains on discarded halves. Arrangement may be fanned on a plate or piled in a bowl. The person might be scooping, dicing, or transferring the slices to a dish or salad.

slicing_bread.progress_description: Loaf on board, intact or partially separated from crust. Crust color ranges from pale tan to deep amber; interior crumb pale cream with visible air pockets. When in progress, a bread knife is mid-through with alternating saw motion; the blade may be angled, crumbs shed along the cut, steam rising, the first partial slice thickness evident. The person holds the knife, steadying with the non-dominant hand, eyes on the edge, applying gentle, rhythmic pressure.
slicing_bread.finished_description: End state: a loaf with evenly cut slices, consistent thickness (roughly 1/4–3/8 inch), arranged in a neat stack or lined on a board. Crust golden-brown, outside slightly firmer; interior crumb pale tan, moist, with uniform air pockets. The sliced loaf shows clean knife marks. The person finished might be wiping the knife, stacking slices into a bread bag or container, or transferring slices to a plate or toaster, ready to eat or toast.

slicing_pear.progress_description: Start: a whole pear with smooth yellow-green skin, compact pear shape, stem on top. In-progress: knife tip and blade engage the body, creating a shallow cut; the flesh beneath is pale and juicy, with a slight translucent sheen. Partial slices or wedges appear as the blade advances; the fruit is stabilized with the other hand, skin still partially on, seeds and core not fully exposed. Surface may show moisture and faint fibrous lines.
slicing_pear.finished_description: End state: uniform pear slices or wedges, typically with the core removed and seeds not visible. Each slice about 5–8 mm thick; pale ivory flesh with green-yellow skin; surface moist, slightly glossy; cut surfaces show crisp but tender texture; minor browning may appear if exposed to air. The person may be arranging slices on a board, placing them into a bowl, brushing with lemon juice, or prepping for a dish.

slicing_steak.progress_description: In progress slices show a knife still at work through the steak. A shallow incision or a growing line of cuts marks the muscle, with partial segmentation but pieces still attached. The surface glistens with juices; marbling and fiber are visible along the cut, and the outer crust or sear may be present. The steak remains broadly whole, shape and size largely intact, while the chef steadies the steak and guides the blade at an angle.
slicing_steak.finished_description: End state: steak is cut into uniform slices about 1/4–1/2 inch thick, with clean, straight cuts and a visible Maillard crust. The interior shows even color from pink to brown depending on doneness; juices gloss the surface, with rendered fat along the edges. Slices are neatly fanned or stacked on a warm plate, ready to serve. The person finished slicing might plate the portions, taste-test, or transfer the dish to a waiter.

slicing_pineapple.progress_description: Start state: whole pineapple with leafy crown and patterned brown-green rind. In-progress state: knife in contact, rind partially removed or scored, pale yellow flesh visible where skin is lifted. Cut surfaces are glossy and fibrous, with juice beads. Slices vary in thickness and shape; the core may be exposed but not fully separated. The fruit is rotated on a cutting board; the operator's hands apply steady, even pressure while guiding the knife.
slicing_pineapple.finished_description: End state: peeled pineapple with the core removed, fruit cut into uniform pieces (cubes about 2 cm or round wedges) with clean, smooth edges. Flesh bright yellow, juicy and firm; rind and eyes gone. Pieces are evenly sized for consistent cooking or eating. After slicing, the person may transfer pieces to a bowl or tray, and then dice further, plate, or begin cooking prep, while cleaning the knife and cutting board.

slicing_radish.progress_description: Start or intermediate states: whole radish with red skin and white flesh; surface damp. A shallow cut reveals pale interior. Partial rounds or slabs show uneven thickness; some skin remains, some flesh exposed. The blade may be angled or in a rocking motion; a hand steadies the radish while the other guides the knife, rotating the vegetable for subsequent passes. Edges are jagged and moisture beads appear where cut.
slicing_radish.finished_description: End state: radish slices are uniform—thin discs (about 2–3 mm) or neat half-moons—with smooth edges. Skin red, interior white or pale pink, crisp and juicy, with a slight glossy sheen. Wedges or rounds are neatly arranged or piled, no torn pieces, some surface moisture. After slicing, the person might assemble a salad, sprinkle salt, or transfer slices to a bowl or plate, then clean the knife.

slicing_peach.progress_description: Starting from a whole peach with fuzzy skin, red-orange blush, and a glossy surface. In progress, a knife has punctured skin and begun a curved cut, exposing pale orange flesh; juice beads on the surface. The fruit is rotated; the flesh shows fibrous texture, slight translucence, and the pit cavity visible. Partial wedges or segments remain attached; skin may peel away in places as slices migrate inward.
slicing_peach.finished_description: End state: evenly cut peach wedges or slices, about 0.5–1 cm thick, flesh yellow-orange with pink blush, juicy and glossy, skin peeled or mostly removed with the pit cavity clean. Pieces are separated and arranged on a board, plate, or in a bowl. The person finished slicing may be transferring slices to a container or prepping them for salad, dessert, or cooking.

slicing_bacon.progress_description: Start/intermediate states of slicing bacon: a whole slab on a cutting board; raw pink flesh with white fat marbling; surface glossy and slightly moist. In-progress shows partial separation: slices beginning to detach, but still attached by connective tissue; uneven thickness; edges may curl. The knife or hands are mid-stroke, blade angled or vertical, lifting a partially cut segment; visible knife marks and dampness.
slicing_bacon.finished_description: End state of slicing bacon: uniformly cut rectangles about 1/8 inch thick, width consistent with the slab, edges clean and straight, corners square. Color: pale pink meat with white fat marbling; surface slightly glossy; texture flexible but firm, not torn. Next actions: slicer’s hands may stack, align into a neat pile or fan into a pan-ready tray, bag, or wrap for refrigeration.

slicing_jalapeno.progress_description: At the start, a whole jalapeño sits on the cutting board: curved, 4–7 cm, glossy dark green skin, firm and crisp. In progress, a shallow blade groove runs along the length; the pepper is partially opened but not fully separated. Interior flesh is lighter green with white pith and seeds near the core; surface may sheen with juice. The preparer steadies the pepper with one hand and guides the blade with deliberate motion, rotating as needed.
slicing_jalapeno.finished_description: End state: uniform jalapeño slices, circular or crescent shapes about 2–4 mm thick, fresh-glossy emerald skin, pale green to white flesh, crisp and juicy. Membrane and seeds largely removed, with some stray seeds possible. Edges clean and smooth, slices arranged flat or in a small pile. After slicing, the person may transfer slices to a bowl or cutting-board, then dice or julienne, or add to dish.

slicing_celery.progress_description: In early stages, whole celery stalks lie on a cutting board: pale to vibrant green ribs with stringy fibers and a moist, crisp interior. When slicing is in progress, some stalks are partially cut, cross-sections exposed, uneven thickness, remaining uncut portions still attached. The person holds a knife, stacks or aligns several stalks, guides the blade with fingers tucked, chops in a steady rhythm, trims ends, and sometimes rinses or dries stalks before continuing.
slicing_celery.finished_description: End state: celery is sliced into uniform pieces with clean knife edges. Depending on technique, pieces appear as sticks (long, uniform length) or rounds (evenly cut disks); typical thickness around 0.5–1 cm. Colors range from bright green to pale-green near the core; texture crisp and dry, with no bruising or stringy fibers. After slicing, the person may transfer pieces to a bowl or tray, rinse, season, or proceed to dice or sauté.

slicing_butter.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: A cold butter block (pale yellow, glossy surface, firm yet sliceable) rests on a board. The knife blade meets the edge; a shallow groove or faint crack appears as pressure is applied. Small shavings curl or cling to the blade; the surface may bulge or compress locally. The person grips the knife, aligns the cut, and pushes or drags the blade forward or downward, guiding the cut to continue.
slicing_butter.finished_description: End state: evenly cut butter pieces—pats, slices, or cubes—laid on a board or in a dish; each piece 0.5–1 cm thick or similar, uniform in size with clean, straight edges. Color pale yellow to ivory, glossy surface, cold and firm yet sliceable; minimal crumbling. The person may be setting pats on bread or into a pan, or transferring pieces to a recipe or storage.

slicing_olive.progress_description: During start or mid-slice, olives vary from whole, glossy ovals to partially cut segments. Skin is firm, color ranges from bright green to deep purple-black; interior flesh is pale, sometimes translucent near the blade. Partial cuts show shallow kerfs, uneven thickness, or a wedge still attached at one end; the blade may indent, twist, or slide, with occasional juice. The cutter stabilizes with the other hand, makes short strokes, and may rotate the olive for alignment.
slicing_olive.finished_description: End state: olives sliced into uniform disks or half-moons arranged on the board. Shape: round cross-sections or curved wedges. Size: thin slices about 1–2 mm thick or small chunks. Color: bright green, olive green, or purplish brown depending on variety; surface smooth and glossy; moisture present; pits removed or cut around. The task is completed; the person might be scooping, piling, or transferring slices to a bowl, salad, or pan, or setting them aside for marination.

slicing_mozzarella.progress_description: At the start, a white mozzarella block sits intact. In progress, the blade is mid-entry, leaving a shallow cut; parallel knife marks mar the surface. The block may tilt, a partially separated slab still attached along fibers. Cheese strings cling to the blade; the paste feels soft, elastic, and cool, with a moist sheen where cut. The person holds the knife, applying steady pressure, possibly rotating or lifting as slicing continues.
slicing_mozzarella.finished_description: End state: uniform, circular or oval mozzarella slices, pale white to ivory, a few millimeters thick, with smooth edges and a glossy, slightly moist surface. Texture is soft and elastic, showing a light pull when separated. The slicer operator may be stacking slices for sandwiches or pizzas, plating them on a platter, or transferring them to a packaging tray.

slicing_orange.progress_description: Start: a whole orange, round to flattened, 6–8 cm diameter, bright orange rind with tiny pores, a white pith ring, and a glossy, dimpled skin. In progress: knife tip or blade piercing the rind, partial cut through the segment walls; rind may be pierced but not detached. Flesh appears moist and orange, with visible membranes and juice beads. The fruit is held or rotated; grip steady, pressure applied, aiming to deepen the cut.
slicing_orange.finished_description: End state: The orange is peeled and cut into wedge-shaped segments. Bright orange flesh is juicy and glossy, separated by thin translucent membranes; a pale pith rim may remain. Segments are roughly uniform in size, about 2–3 cm across, with the rind mostly removed. The person may be arranging the slices on a plate, removing remaining membranes, or proceeding to juice or eat them.

slicing_ham.progress_description: Start or in-progress states of slicing ham: A whole ham sits on a cutting board, rind and fat cap visible; the surface is pink with white marbling. The knife engages the meat, making shallow, guided cuts; the cut faces show a fresh, slightly glistening pink interior with visible muscle fibers. In mid-progress, partial slices appear along the blade path or on the board, thickness variable, edges smooth or slightly torn, ham steady under the hand.
slicing_ham.finished_description: End state: evenly sliced ham pieces with uniform thickness, typically 2–5 mm for deli cuts or 4–6 mm for home use. Cross-sections are pink-rose with white fat rims; surfaces moist and slightly glossy; edges clean and smooth, free of ragged fibers; bite is firm and springy. Slices are often fanned on a tray or neatly stacked, sometimes trimmed of rind. The worker may be stacking/arranging portions, portioning, or wrapping.

slicing_lime.progress_description: Start or intermediate states show the lime held steady, rind intact or partly scored. A knife blade enters the rind and flesh, creating a shallow groove or partial arc; the exposed pulp is pale green, glistening with juice, and the vesicles are visible. Parts of the zest and rind remain joined, forming partial wedges. Moisture beads on cut surfaces; the person steadies with one hand and slices with controlled pressure, angling as they progress.
slicing_lime.finished_description: End state: lime pieces ready for use. The rind remains green and glossy; flesh is pale, translucent green, moist and juicy. If sliced crosswise, circular disks show a white pith ring and radial segments; if cut into wedges, triangles with rind on one side and pointed tips. Pieces are typically 1–3 cm thick (wedges) or 0.5–1 cm (slices). Seeds may be present unless removed. The person may be squeezing juice, plating wedges, or garnishing a drink/dish.

slicing_almond.progress_description: Start or intermediate states: An almond, oval and 1–2 cm long, with brown skin over a pale, hard kernel. In progress, you see blade marks, shallow crosscuts, partial splits exposing white interior, and thin curls of skin or small fragments on the board; jagged edges where the blade has bitten. The slicer stabilizes the nut, grips firmly, and uses downward or sawing motions, rotating the almond for further cutting.
slicing_almond.finished_description: End state: uniform almond slices (slivers): flat, crescent-shaped pieces about 2–3 mm thick and 8–12 mm long; skin mostly removed, interior pale ivory with light brown edges; dry, crisp texture (slightly chewy if toasted); smooth edges and consistent size. When toasting, they turn golden-brown with aroma. After slicing, the person may toast them, scatter on salad or yogurt, bake into pastries, or use as garnish.

slicing_cheese.progress_description: Start or intermediate states show a cheese block or wheel with a knife entering or resting in mid-thickness. The exposed face is glossy and matches the rind or interior (cream, ivory, yellow, or orange). The cut sheet may be thin and tentative or thicker, still attached at one edge. The block shows scoring lines, curls, or crumbly edges if soft. The person grips the handle, steadies the block, and applies a guiding sawing motion.
slicing_cheese.finished_description: End state: evenly cut cheese slices with uniform thickness, edges clean and smooth. Shape varies by cut: rectangular slabs from blocks; crescent/straight edges from a wheel. Colors range from pale ivory to yellow-orange, with a glossy surface and a firm, sliceable texture. Slices may be aligned in a stack or fanned on a plate, ready to serve or refrigerate. The person may wipe the knife, transfer slices to a platter, and cover or store the cheese.

slicing_pepperoni.progress_description: At the start, a pepperoni disk rests on a cutting board—round, palm-sized, deep red with white fat marbling; surface glossy, oily, and pliable. As slicing begins, shallow knife marks appear and the blade nudges through portions of the edge. In progress, some slices are partially separated yet remain attached, forming a partial fan or stacked segments. The cutter holds a knife, uses a steady, downward stroke and readjusts angle between passes, watching thickness and alignment.
slicing_pepperoni.finished_description: End state: a neat spread of uniformly sized pepperoni rounds laid flat on the board. Each slice is about 1–2 inches (2.5–5 cm) in diameter and 1–2 mm thick, glossy red-brown with white fat specks. Edges are smooth and uniform; some slight curling may occur after air-drying or heating. The slicer, finished, might stack or plate the slices, place them on dough or a tray, or wipe the blade.

chopping_onion.progress_description: In early stages, a whole onion with dry papery skin, then peeled halves on the board. The layers appear translucent as cuts begin. Slices form curved half-moon shapes; chunks vary from large to medium as the knife motions. Color ranges from white to pale yellow; surface is crisp yet glistening with moisture. The person steadies with a non-dominant hand and makes measured vertical or horizontal cuts, keeping rhythm.
chopping_onion.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped onion pieces—small dice (≈3–5 mm) or finer minces/brunoise as required—translucent pale white to light yellow, moist and glossy, with no visible uncut rings. A neat mound sits on the cutting board or in a bowl; most pieces are similar size with minimal variation. The cook may transfer them to a pan or bowl, wipe the knife/board, or prep for cooking.

chopping_garlic.progress_description: Start/in-progress states: whole cloves with papery skin, sometimes peeled; on the board, some halves or cracks appear. As chopping proceeds, the cloves break into irregular chunks and slivers—varying sizes from thin ribbons to chunky bits—color pale ivory with a slight yellow tint; surfaces appear moist, edges sometimes glossy. The person uses a rocking or straight-down knife motion, moving the garlic with the non-knife hand and pushing scraps aside, not yet forming uniform pieces.
chopping_garlic.finished_description: End state: finely minced garlic—uniform tiny pieces about 1–2 mm, pale white to pale yellow, with slightly translucent edges. The texture is moist, paste-like when pressed, with a sharp aroma. Small scraps of papery skin may remain on the board. Next, the cook might scoop it into a pan or bowl, or start sautéing in oil, stirring to prevent burning.

chopping_tomato.progress_description: Start: a whole tomato on a cutting board, glossy red skin, green stem. In progress: knife sinks into tomato or presses through a half, forming partial slices or irregular wedges; seeds visible, interior flesh lighter pink; juice beads and surface moisture; sizes vary from thin rounds to chunky chunks; shapes shift from round to angular. The cutter stabilizes with the non-dominant hand, fingers curled, guiding a slicing or light rocking motion.
chopping_tomato.finished_description: End state: uniformly diced tomatoes (cubes about 5–8 mm) or finely minced for sauces, bright red with a glossy surface, seeds and pulp evenly distributed, minimal juice leakage, no large chunks. The knife and board are clean. The person might scoop the chopped tomatoes into a bowl or pan, transfer to a pot, or begin sautéing or adding to a dish.

chopping_apple.progress_description: At the start, the apple is whole or in halves. In intermediate states, skin may be red, green, or yellow, with pale white flesh and a central core. Cut pieces vary as slender sticks, cubes, or irregular chunks; some surfaces are exposed, others still skin-covered. Flesh can be crisp and juicy, sometimes browning where cut. The knife is mid-stroke, hands guiding; fingers curled, palm flat on the board. Seeds are sometimes visible.
chopping_apple.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut apple pieces (diced or sliced) about 0.5–1.5 cm; pale white flesh with exposed edges; skin showing red, green, or yellow. Surfaces may be glossy and crisp, with minimal browning. Pieces sit in a pile, bowl, or on a cutting board; knife laid aside or nearby. The person might be transferring pieces to a bowl, adding to a pan, or whisking or mixing ingredients for a recipe.

chopping_parsley.progress_description: During chopping, parsley on the board appears in in-progress pieces: leaf fragments and stem shreds, irregular shapes, and varying sizes from a few millimeters to rough strips. Colors range bright to dark greens, with glossy, damp surfaces from washing. The texture alternates between delicate leaf bits and tougher, fibrous stems. The cook uses a rocking knife, gathers, and recuts; motions include chopping, regrouping, and sampling the pile.
chopping_parsley.finished_description: End state: finely chopped parsley—uniform, small pieces about 1–3 mm; bright green throughout; dry to slightly damp and fluffy; no large stems or whole leaves visible; scattered flecks evenly distributed. After chopping, the person may scoop or pour the chopped parsley into a bowl or directly sprinkle it over a dish, wipe the knife, and set the board aside or rinse the knife.

chopping_carrot.progress_description: At the start: a whole carrot, bright orange, tapered, uncut, lying on a cutting board. In progress: carrot partially sliced—some rounds or baton shapes with uneven edges; intact portions next to exposed cross-sections; surface moist, crisp, fibrous. Color contrast between orange exterior and lighter interior. Knife blade oriented downward, one hand stabilizing the carrot, the other guiding the cut. The scene shows active chopping but no finished pieces visible.
chopping_carrot.finished_description: End state: evenly sized carrot pieces with clean, flat faces. Common forms: dice (~5 mm) or julienne/batons (2–3 mm thick x 5–6 cm long). Color bright orange; texture crisp yet tender; surface dry to the touch, no ragged edges. Pieces are grouped on the board or in a bowl, ready for cooking. The person may wipe the board, wipe the knife, or begin sautéing, boiling, or adding to a recipe.

chopping_pepper.progress_description: State: A bell pepper on a cutting board, skin glossy in red/green/yellow, with the top cut away. The pepper is partially sliced: vertical incisions extend into the flesh, leaving irregular wedges or strips still attached to the core. The interior flesh is pale and moist; seeds cling to the pale pith. A chef's hand steadies the pepper while the knife is halfway through a cut; fingers curled back, blade mid-stroke. Drops of juice bead on surface.
chopping_pepper.finished_description: End state: peppers cleaned, seeded, and cut into uniform pieces (dice about 6 to 8 mm cubes, or thin julienne strips). Surfaces glossy, crisp-tender; interiors pale and moist; skins bright green, red, orange, or yellow. Seeds gone, membranes reduced to small bits. Pieces evenly sized, no large chunks. The chopped pepper sits ready in a bowl or on the board. The person may transfer to a pan, add to a dish, or wipe tools and bowl.

chopping_mushroom.progress_description: In progress, mushrooms lie on a cutting board in a mixed state: some whole, some sliced, others in uneven slivers. Caps and stems show cross‑sections with pale, spongy flesh that’s moist and slightly translucent at the cut faces. Shapes range from small chips to thin ribbons and thicker cobblestones; colors from ivory to light brown, with damp sheen. The knife is mid-stroke, fingers tucked, guiding the blade as the person makes shallow cuts without finishing.
chopping_mushroom.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut mushrooms, either coins (2–6 mm thick) or small dice (2–5 mm). Colors pale white to light brown; flesh firm and moist; cut surfaces clean and smooth, with no browning or bruising. Pieces are loosely scattered or gathered in a bowl. Once chopped, the person is likely to transfer them to a pan for sautéing, season them, or add them to a recipe.

chopping_bacon.progress_description: At the start or during chopping, bacon appears as thin flat slabs with pink lean and white fat, glistening with moisture. Edges are jagged and fragments vary: whole strips still intact, half-sliced pieces, and uneven chips or shreds with irregular thickness. Surfaces are sticky and greasy, with exposed marbling and pale-fat margins. The cutter grips the knife and uses a brief rocking or straight-down motion, pausing between cuts while fragments accumulate.
chopping_bacon.finished_description: End state: chopped bacon appears as irregular, small pieces or dice, roughly 3–8 mm, with a mix of pink-red meat and white fat; some pieces have translucent edges and a greasy sheen; pieces vary in lean-to-fat ratio and shape, often piled on the board. After chopping, the person may move to a hot pan to render and fry, or add the bits to a dish and begin sautéing until crisp.

chopping_cilantro.progress_description: Start state: cilantro bunch with stems and leaves intact, bright green, damp from washing; on a cutting board. In-progress states: unevenly chopped, some 2–5 mm pieces, many 5–12 mm fragments, jagged leaf edges, longer stems remaining. Colors range from vivid green to slightly darker mid-green; texture varies from crisp-cut leaf to fibrous stem. The person holds a knife with a rocking motion, gathers and occasionally sweeps pieces toward one side, performing partial chopping while continuing work.
chopping_cilantro.finished_description: End state: cilantro finely minced into uniform, small pieces (~2–4 mm), mixture of bright green leaves with light-green stems; evenly distributed, slightly damp from rinsing; no large stems or whole leaves. The chopped cilantro sits in a small mound or scattered across a cutting board or bowl. Next steps: the person deposits it into a dish or pan, sprinkles over food, or sweeps tools away and cleans the knife and board.

chopping_spinach.progress_description: In-progress spinach chopping shows leaves and stems still largely intact or torn into irregular ribbons. Pieces range from whole leaves to 0.5–2 cm fragments, with jagged edges and glossy dark-green surfaces, some lighter veins exposed. Leaves may appear wilted from washing, with damp sheen. The knife is mid-stroke, creating uneven shreds; fingers hover near the blade, guiding the pile while the board accumulates chopped bits. The motion is rhythmic, with varying piece sizes.
chopping_spinach.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped spinach with small pieces (roughly 2–5 mm), evenly green ribbons/mince, no whole leaves or thick stems. Leaves dark green, slightly wilted from cutting, moisture present but not soggy; pieces loosely piled or spread in a shallow layer. Next steps: transfer to a bowl or pan, squeeze out excess moisture if needed, then sauté, fold into a dish, or blanch as the recipe requires.

chopping_cabbage.progress_description: Start state: whole cabbage with tightly packed pale-green leaves and a compact white core on a cutting board. Intermediate states: halves, quarters, loose outer leaves removed; visible knife edges, crosscuts and planing marks; irregularly sized pieces, ribbons or chunks, some moisture glistening; color variations from bright green to pale white; surface textures ranging from crisp to damp. In-progress actions: the person holds the knife, makes downward chops, slides pieces aside, reorganizes pile.
chopping_cabbage.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut cabbage into thin shreds or small cubes, roughly a few millimeters across. Color pale green to white; interior remains crisp with a slightly glossy surface. Moisture is minimal; outer leaves removed and pieces evenly sized. After chopping, the person may transfer to a bowl, pat dry or rinse, then mix into slaw, sauté, or use as a garnish or ingredient in a recipe.

chopping_nut.progress_description: Start/intermediate states include whole nuts in shells, or nuts already cracked into halves and jagged fragments. Shell color: brown mottled; kernels pale beige to light brown, with an oily sheen. Pieces range from intact halves to chipped shards; surfaces can be smooth or rough, with cracks. In progress, the artisan grips a knife or cleaver, applies rocking or tapping force on a cutting board, guiding pieces apart while keeping fingers clear of the blade.
chopping_nut.finished_description: End state: irregular, bite-sized nut pieces, 1–5 mm; a mix of slivers and chunks with some fine crumbs; color ranges from light tan to brown, surface lightly glossy from natural oil; texture crunchy with crumbly edges; no whole nuts present. After chopping: the person scoops into a bowl or pan, wipes the knife and board, and proceeds to toast or mix into a recipe.

chopping_banana.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: A yellow banana on a cutting board, intact or peeled, with brown speckles; pale ivory flesh visible where peeled. Early progress shows a knife near or just entering the fruit, yielding curved slices or irregular chunks about 0.5–1.5 cm. Partial peel remains; surface moisture and fibers visible; fruit ranges from firm to slightly soft. The person grips the knife firmly, guiding a clean stroke while stabilizing the banana with the other hand.
chopping_banana.finished_description: End state: peeled banana pieces laid out as uniform chunks or rounds. Size about 0.5–1 cm (dice) or 0.5–1 cm thick slices. Color: pale yellow interior; surface moist, with possible light browning on exposed surfaces. Texture: soft to creamy, cut surfaces slightly friable. Pieces gathered on the cutting board or in a bowl; discarded peel nearby or placed aside. The person may be pouring into a bowl, mixing with other ingredients, or proceeding to cook/bake.

chopping_strawberry.progress_description: In early or intermediate stages, whole berries with shallow cuts or partial slicing; some are halved or have vertical incisions, exposing bright red flesh and pale core. Skin remains glossy and damp; seeds are visible. Green calyx may be attached or trimmed. A knife is in mid-stroke or resting near the cutting board while the person steadies the berry, guides the blade downward, and applies pressure, producing irregular blade marks and juice on the surface.
chopping_strawberry.finished_description: Ending state: uniformly cut strawberries, often in neat pieces such as dice (about 5–8 mm) or thin half-moons, with red exterior and pale interior, seeds visible, and removed green caps. Pieces are firm yet juicy, not jagged. The board shows clusters of diced cubes or sliced rounds, with juice beads. The person may transfer pieces to a bowl, wipe the board, or mix into a recipe.

chopping_cucumber.progress_description: On the cutting board, a cucumber sits whole or partly cut. The skin is bright green and glossy; the pale, crisp flesh near the blade is exposed. Some cross-sections show partial rounds or long sticks still attached at a few points. The knife is mid-slice, fingers guiding it; edges are uneven, with irregular thickness and visible seeds. Moisture beads form, and small fragments or slivers may lie nearby as chopping progresses.
chopping_cucumber.finished_description: End state: uniform cucumber pieces ready for use. Shapes: rounds (2–4 mm thick), batons (3–5 mm by ~6–20 mm), or small dice (~3–6 mm). Colors: bright green skin with pale green flesh; moist, crisp, with clean, straight edges. No large scraps, minimal bruising. After chopping, the person typically transfers pieces to a bowl or plate, or to a pot/container, then may rinse, season, or store.

chopping_chocolate.progress_description: Start and intermediate states show irregular chocolate blocks or slabs with diverse surface textures—glossy after tempering, or matte and chalky if grainy. Edges are jagged; shards, slivers, and small nuggets of mixed sizes remain attached or loose. Color ranges deep brown to coppery, sometimes with bloom. Knife marks, cracks, and chips appear as the piece is pressed, tapped, and re‑positioned by the person to split the block further.
chopping_chocolate.finished_description: End state: a pile of irregular chocolate pieces—chips, shards, and chunks—ranging from a few millimeters to a couple of centimeters. Color mirrors the bar (dark, milk, or white). Surfaces can be glossy or matte; edges are jagged or clean depending on knife. They’re solid, dry, and unmelted. The person is likely collecting them into a bowl for melting, weighing, or transferring to a recipe, then cleaning the workspace.

chopping_rosemary.progress_description: Start/intermediate state: intact rosemary sprigs with woody stems and dense, narrow dark-green needles; a light gray-green bloom and residual moisture from washing. In progress, the knife cuts through the sprigs, yielding mixed sizes—from long shards to short fragments and tiny specks—while some needles stay attached. Surfaces look glossy and slightly oily. The person steers a rocking or push-cut motion, gathering newly sliced bits toward the blade or onto the cutting board.
chopping_rosemary.finished_description: End state: rosemary is finely chopped into small, irregular fragments. Color ranges bright to mid-green needles, with the occasional pale stem. Size about 1–3 mm pieces, some longer slivers if not fully minced. Texture is herbaceous and slightly oily from essential oils; crumbly but cohesive, not powdery. Once chopped, the cook might sprinkle it into a pan, stir into a sauce or marinade, or scoop up the chopped herb.

chopping_chive.progress_description: Initial: a bundle of fresh chives, dark green tops fading to pale white roots, long slender stalks with crisp texture; whole or loosely tied. In progress: knife slices ahead, producing a mix of long uncut sections, mid-length pieces, and fine green fragments. Colors range from bright green to pale fringe where cuts occur; texture transitions from crisp to torn. The cook gathers, trims uneven ends, and continues chopping with a rocking or straight motion.
chopping_chive.finished_description: End state: uniformly minced chives—tiny, slender green pieces roughly 2–4 mm long, with bright green color and a hint of white at the base. They appear fresh, crisp, and slightly fluffy, forming a neat pile or a light sprinkle across the board. The person might be scooping the chopped chives into a small bowl or sprinkling them over a dish, then wiping the board and cleaning the knife.

chopping_shallot.progress_description: Intermediate states show peeled shallots with papery skin, or peeled halves with translucent, pale yellow flesh. In progress, expect uneven cuts: thin slivers, small chunks, and partial rings, some pieces still connected. Surfaces are moist and slightly glossy; flesh may take on a faint purple tint. The person grips the knife in a pinch, guiding with knuckles, using rocking or chopping motions, gathering loose bits into a pile as cuts continue.
chopping_shallot.finished_description: End state: uniform small dice or minced pieces of shallot, about 2–3 mm cubes (or fine mince), with skin removed, flesh pale translucent pink-white, slightly glossy. Pieces are soft, moist, and cohesive, with no large chunks or strong fibrous bands. On the board, a neat pile or spread of evenly sized bits. The person may be sweeping the knife clean, transferring the chopped shallots to a pan or bowl, or scraping into a container for use.

chopping_peanut.progress_description: Starting state: whole peanut with shell, or single kernel. In progress: shells cracked with jagged edges; kernels split into halves or irregular chunks. Colors range from pale beige to light brown; skins loosened, oil sheen emerging. Texture spans crisp fragments to crumbly shreds. Some bits remain attached by thin membranes. The worker grips the knife or mallet, applies press or whacks; continually guides pieces to shape, with uneven, stop-and-go motion.
chopping_peanut.finished_description: End state: chopped peanuts appear as small, irregular pieces or uniform granules, roughly 1–5 mm (or finer if ground). Colors range from pale tan to medium brown with a dry, crisp texture; shells removed and minimal oil sheen. When done, the person scoops or pours the nuts into a bowl or pan, wipes the knife/board, and may measure, season, or sprinkle the bits atop a dish.

chopping_vegetable.progress_description: Start or in-progress states: whole vegetables with skin, or partially cut. On the board lie slices, sticks, wedges, and irregular chunks in varying sizes. Surfaces show fresh cut edges, some with glaze of moisture; color contrasts between skin and pale flesh. Textures range from firm to crisp. The person holds a knife in a claw grip, guiding a downward or rocking cut, while the other hand stabilizes and nudges pieces apart, not finished yet.
chopping_vegetable.finished_description: End state: vegetables are cut into uniform pieces—diced cubes (about 5–8 mm), brunoise (1–2 mm dice), or julienne strips (2–3 mm by 4–5 cm)—with clean, freshly cut surfaces. Colors remain vibrant; pieces may be lightly damp from rinsing. No large or ragged chunks. They pile in a bowl or on the board, ready for sautéing or mixing. The person might transfer to a pan, toss into a pot, or add to a salad.

chopping_herb.progress_description: Early in chopping, herb shows loose leaves and stems, sometimes torn edges. Pieces range from larger leaf chunks to thin ribbons and tiny bits stuck to the blade, with moist green surfaces and pale veins. Edges are jagged or ragged; some pieces curl or wilt. The board holds uneven thickness and juice. The preparer grips the knife in a pinch grip, uses a rocking or push-cut, and guides the other hand to gather the pile forward.
chopping_herb.finished_description: End state: chopped herb appears as small, uniform pieces (mince) or thin ribbons (chiffonade), not whole leaves. Size ~1–3 mm for mince; ribbons a few millimeters wide. Color stays vivid green (or purple for some varieties) with a soft, loose, slightly moist texture. Stems mostly removed; pieces cling together loosely. The herb is gathered into a pile or bowl. The person is scraping the knife, sweeping the board, or transferring to a dish or pot.

chopping_kale.progress_description: During chopping, kale exists as irregular pieces: large leaves torn from stems, narrow ribbons, and chunky chunks. Colors range from dark green to lighter green with pale midribs. Surfaces may be glossy from moisture. Knife is cutting or lifting; fresh cut faces, jagged edges, and uneven thickness appear. Some stems are partially trimmed; remaining bits show fibrous texture. The pile is uneven, with varying cohesion and scattered fragments; motion may be paused or ongoing.
chopping_kale.finished_description: End state: kale is uniformly chopped into bite-sized pieces (roughly 0.4–0.8 cm), often in chiffonade ribbons or small cubes; leaves are dark green with lighter veins and stems removed; surface is dry to slightly moist and crisp-tender; pieces are loosely piled with even size and no large shreds. Next: the person may be massaging the kale with lemon juice or oil for tenderness, or moving it to a bowl or pan to dress or cook.

chopping_celery.progress_description: In-progress celery: whole stalks alongside a knife, some stalks already sliced. Pieces range from thin slivers to chunks of uneven lengths. Exposed cross-sections show pale green centers with white ribs and stringy fibers. Surfaces remain crisp, with visible moisture and slight sheen. The cook’s hands grip the knife, guide the blade with curled fingers, sometimes stacking mid-cut pieces on the board or pulling remaining stalks toward them.
chopping_celery.finished_description: End state: celery pieces are uniform and ready for use. Shapes include small dice (roughly 3–5 mm) or matchsticks (2–3 cm long) with clean, straight edges. Color: crisp green stalks with pale white cores; texture: crisp, moist, with no limp or stringy fibers. The pieces are evenly sized, free of scraps. After chopping, the person might transfer to a bowl or pan, rinse the knife, or start sautéing/dropping into a pot or salad.

chopping_mint.progress_description: During start/intermediate chopping, the board shows whole mint leaves and stems, some torn or folded, with a mix of large leaf fragments and smaller cut bits. Pieces vary from ribbon-thin shreds to irregular chunks, edges jagged where knife has scored. Color ranges from bright to mid-green, with a glossy, slightly damp surface. The knife is mid-stroke, creating partial slices; stems may still be intact or only partly cut. The pile appears uneven and in motion.
chopping_mint.finished_description: End state: finely chopped mint leaves in uniform, small pieces about 2–4 mm; bright emerald green with dark veins; loose, fluffy texture, not paste, with a light, fresh aroma. Stems mostly trimmed; moisture present but not soggy. The person may be sprinkling the mint over a dish, folding it into a sauce or salsa, or transferring it to a bowl to add to the recipe, then wiping the board.

chopping_dill.progress_description: During chopping, dill is only partially cut: some fronds remain whole or in long ribbons, others broken into uneven shards. The pieces range from slender threadlike stems to short, jagged leaflets. Colors stay bright green with moist sheen on freshly cut surfaces. A knife hovers or glides with a light rocking motion; fingers balance sprigs, gathering and guiding them. The pile displays mixed textures—intact sprigs, coiled tips, and scattered fragments—without uniform granularity.
chopping_dill.finished_description: End state: dill is finely minced into small, uniform fragments about 2–3 mm long. Leaves and tender stems are chopped to an even, fluffy texture with no large pieces or visible stems. Color is bright to medium green, slightly lighter in finer portions; the surface may look glossy from moisture. A loose mound sits on board, not a paste. The person may rest the knife, gather the dill, or transfer it to a dish for garnish.

chopping_mango.progress_description: During chopping, the mango is partially peeled or unpeeled, with orange flesh exposed, glossy or fibrous. Knife blades leave parallel score lines or incomplete wedges; pieces may be still attached to the pit or rind. Shapes range from curved crescents to rough blocks where some skin remains. The surface may glisten with juice; the person holds the fruit with a nonslip hand, uses a rocking or straight chopping motion, and pauses to reposition or trim skin.
chopping_mango.finished_description: End state: mango flesh peeled and pitted, cut into uniform dice about 5–10 mm or into parallel strips. Color bright orange, glossy, moist; edges clean, minimal stringy fibers; arranged in a bowl or pile on a board, juices present. When done, the person may transfer pieces to a bowl, add to a recipe, blend, or wipe the board and wash the knife.

chopping_chicken.progress_description: Start: a whole or bone-in piece sits pale pink, glossy, with skin and visible fat; surface damp. As cutting begins, the knife leaves clean, angular cuts and fiber disruption. In progress, you see irregular chunks and strips of various sizes—from roughly 1–3 cm to larger fragments—some still connected by membranes or bone. Surfaces are pale interior, moist and slightly translucent; edges jagged or beveled; some pieces show stringy connective tissue or fat, revealing ongoing separation.
chopping_chicken.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut chicken pieces, typically 1–2 cm cubes or thin strips, with clean edges and no bones. Raw flesh appears pink-white with slight translucence and moisture on the surface; pieces are evenly sized and loosely arranged in a pile or container. After chopping, the person may transfer them to a bowl, start seasoning, or move to a pan for cooking, or wipe the board and wash tools.

chopping_walnut.progress_description: Walnuts start as hard, brown shells around pale kernels. In progress, shells crack into jagged fragments; kernels split into uneven halves or quarters with some pieces still attached to shell shards. Surface textures range from smooth rind to wrinkled nut meat; color shifts from brown shell to light tan interior. Small fragments, powder, or crumbs scatter on the board. The person may tap, crack, slice, or press with a mallet or knife, pausing between passes.
chopping_walnut.finished_description: End state: chopped walnuts are irregular fragments ranging from small chips to larger chunks; shapes jagged with broken halves and facets. Sizes vary, typical pieces a few millimeters across. Color ranges from pale beige to light brown, skins darker, with a glossy, oily surface. Texture can be crisp and slightly crumbly, sometimes sticky if fresh. After chopping, the person may transfer the walnuts to a bowl or pan, wipe the knife, or start toasting.

chopping_leaf.progress_description: During early to mid chopping stages, the leaf shows partial segmentation: some intact sections, others sliced into irregular strips or fragments. Shapes vary from thin shreds to jagged chunks; sizes range from fine to palm-sized. Surfaces are green with exposed pale midribs; cut edges may be lighter or slightly browning. The leaf is moist, with knife marks and juice beads. The person grips and stabilizes the leaf, guiding and repeating the chopping motion.
chopping_leaf.finished_description: End state: chopped leaf pieces are small, irregular shapes with roughly uniform size of about 2–5 mm; color bright to dark green; moist, slightly glossy; stems largely removed; occasional fibrous strands. After chopping, the person may transfer to a bowl or pan, add to a recipe, start sautéing or mixing, or move to another prep station.

chopping_potato.progress_description: Partial chopping state: potato on a board, skin intact or partly peeled. In-progress shapes include long slices, thick sticks, and uneven chunks; some pieces still clinging to the whole. Surfaces show exposed pale starchy flesh, moist and slightly granular, with jagged or clean knife marks. Color contrast: brown skin versus white-yellow interior. Knife hands guide the blade; fingers curled back, one hand stabilizing, the other mid-stroke, with leftover whole portions nearby.
chopping_potato.finished_description: End state: potatoes are cut into uniform pieces—dice or batons—roughly 5–15 mm, with clean, flat faces and few jagged edges. With skin on, skin contrasts with pale interior; skin off, pieces are pale cream. Exposed flesh is white to pale yellow and feels firm. The cook typically transfers to a bowl or pot, rinses, pats dry, then cooks (boil, roast, or fry).

chopping_jalapeno.progress_description: Start state: a whole jalapeño, glossy green skin, stem intact, about five centimeters long. In progress: the knife has begun cuts; a few vertical or crosswise slits, pepper partially opened, seeds and white pith sometimes exposed but not fully removed. Edges are uneven; pieces vary in thickness, some surface moisture darkened from cutting. The person steadies the pepper with fingers away from the blade, and makes measured slicing motions, guiding the knife through the flesh.
chopping_jalapeno.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped jalapeño pieces (small dice or mince), about 2–5 mm. Seeds and membranes largely removed; pieces square or irregular, with crisp, moist texture and glossy green flesh. Color ranges bright to mid-green, with pale interior. After chopping, the person might transfer the chopped jalapeño to a bowl or skillet, start sautéing, or move to the next prep step, while wiping the knife and board.

chopping_zucchini.progress_description: During in-progress chopping, you might see a whole zucchini on the board with intact dark-green skin, or a partially cut stem end. A blade is mid-stroke, slicing a green cylinder into pieces. Partial slices show pale, moist flesh with small seeds; some rounds or sticks are unevenly thick. Pieces range from intact lengthwise halves to fragments; surface moisture glistens; fingers curl back, guiding the knife while the rest remains uncut.
chopping_zucchini.finished_description: End state: zucchini cut into uniform pieces—rounds or cubes—about 0.5–1 cm. Skin green with pale-green flesh; pieces moist and crisp, with no large skin scraps or mushy spots. Seeds minimal in small dice. When finished, the person typically transfers the chopped pieces to a bowl or directly to a pan for sautéing or stir-frying, or adds them to a recipe.

chopping_chili.progress_description: Start or intermediate chopping states show whole chilis or halved peppers on a cutting board, skins taut, flesh exposed. Slices vary from thin coins to rough chunks; some pieces are intact stems or seeds visible. Colors range from green to red, orange, or yellow; moisture beads on surfaces, membranes pale inside cuts. The knife may be in a rocking or chop; the hand holds the chili, fingers curled to guard, gathering fragments as they go.
chopping_chili.finished_description: End state: chili chopped into uniform pieces, either diced (~2–5 mm cubes) or minced into fine bits. Color varies by pepper (red, green, orange); seeds may be present or removed. Pieces are moist with a slight gloss and loosely gathered rather than packed. The person may transfer them to a bowl, scrape the cutting board and knife, wipe the surface, and start sautéing or folding into a sauce.

chopping_egg.progress_description: Start or in-progress egg chopping shows partial disruption on a cutting board: peeled egg halves or whole soft-boiled eggs with knife marks; white albumen and yellow yolk showing, sometimes pale or slightly glossy. When incomplete, pieces vary in shape and size: thin ribbons, irregular slabs, or chunky fragments; some portions remain connected, or yolk may smear against white. The handler is slicing, quartering, or mashing with a knife, pausing between cuts.
chopping_egg.finished_description: End state (hard‑boiled eggs): chopped into irregular but mostly uniform small pieces, roughly 2–5 mm. Egg white remains white; yolk is broken into yellow specks. Texture ranges from crumbly to creamy; no shell. After chopping, the person might add them to a salad or sandwich, fold into a filling, or set them in a bowl while cleaning the board and knife.

chopping_pecan.progress_description: During incomplete chopping, pecans appear as whole nuts or large halves with many pieces still intact. You may see irregular shards, slivers, and chunky fragments, sizes from coarse chunks to crumbs. Colors range from pale beige to toasted tan; edges are jagged and surfaces dusty or oily. They lie loose on a cutting board or in a bowl. The person is slicing, rocking a knife, or pulsing a processor, mid-action.
chopping_pecan.finished_description: End state: irregular, bite-sized pecan pieces, about 2–5 mm, from slivers to chunks. Color ranges pale tan to medium brown with a light oil sheen. Texture is crisp and crumbly; some fine meal dust; generally evenly distributed with few large fragments. The chopper finishes by transferring the chopped pecans to a bowl, pan, or mixing bowl, then wiping the board/knife or measuring and adding to batter.

chopping_ginger.progress_description: Start or intermediate states of chopping ginger: partially peeled skin exposing pale beige flesh; skin fragments remain. Irregular pieces range from slender ribbons to chunky shards; thickness varies. Flesh is fibrous, moist, and pale yellow with visible fibers. Surface is uneven and stringy. On the board, shavings and small pulp flecks accumulate. The person holds the ginger, uses a rocking or straight-down knife motion, and continues cutting without producing uniform pieces.
chopping_ginger.finished_description: End state of chopped ginger: small, uniformly cut pieces with clean, straight-cut surfaces. Color: pale yellow flesh, skin removed; interior remains slightly translucent. Texture: moist and fibrous, with a peppery, aromatic bite. Sizes vary: minced particles about 1 to 2 mm or small dice about 3 to 6 mm. After chopping, the cook might sweep pieces into a bowl, sauté them in oil, or add to a simmering dish; knife and board cleaned.

chopping_coriander.progress_description: Start state: a bunch of cilantro with roots trimmed, stems green and pale, leaves bright green and intact, slightly dewy from rinsing. In progress: knife slices through gathered leaves; some stems being cut; fragments range from torn leaf bits to mid-sized shreds, uneven in width, with some whole leaves still recognizable. Knife motion steady; non-dominant hand guides and stabilizes on the board; a small pile forms, not uniform yet.
chopping_coriander.finished_description: End state: a mound of uniformly minced cilantro leaves and tender stems, mostly 2–4 mm bits, bright emerald green with pale white stems, lightly moist from wash; no large coarse pieces; aroma fresh, crisp texture, even distribution. The person finished might scoop the chopped cilantro into a bowl or onto a dish, wipe the knife clean, or sprinkle it over a finished dish as a garnish.

chopping_basil.progress_description: Starting: whole basil leaves, bright green, with smooth edges and visible veins, attached to slender stems, laid flat on a cutting board. In-progress: leaves torn or folded, some translucent stems exposed; scattered pieces appear as irregular ribbons and small specks, sizes ranging from fragments to slivers about a few millimeters; blade motion, including gentle rocking or straight chops, with fingers curled back and blade hovering above scattered plant matter.
chopping_basil.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped basil—finely minced (1–3 mm) or chiffonade ribbons—bright to mid-green, lightly glossy, free of stems, moist but not soggy, with even size distribution. The chopped bits appear as small, irregular but consistent pieces and catch a fresh aroma. After chopping, the person may transfer them to a bowl or pan, sprinkle over a dish or sauce as garnish, or wipe the knife/board and continue cooking.

chopping_avocado.progress_description: An avocado on a cutting board in early or mid-cut. Skin may be whole and bumpy or peeled to pale green flesh. If halved, the pit stays in one half; exposed flesh is glossy, creamy, and still attached, with knife-scarred surfaces. Pieces range from large wedges to rough chunks. The person steadies the fruit, holds the knife with one hand, and makes shallow, progressive cuts or scoring.
chopping_avocado.finished_description: End state: avocado peeled, pitted, flesh exposed in bright green to yellow-green. Chopped pieces are uniform cubes or irregular chunks about 5–10 mm; surface shows knife-score marks. Texture ranges from chunky yet creamy, not mushy; minimal browning on exposed surfaces unless oxidized. Pieces gathered in a bowl or on the board, ready for mixing. The person may be scooping pieces into a bowl, mashing, or folding in lime and seasoning.

chopping_broccoli.progress_description: Start or intermediate states show: a whole broccoli head with a crown of green florets and a pale, fibrous stalk; buds tightly packed, sometimes with a few florets already detached. In progress, florets are separated into irregular chunks or sticks; stalks are partially sliced into strips; edges vary from jagged to clean. Color remains green on exposed surfaces, with pale white interior where cut. The person holds steady with one hand and chops with a knife.
chopping_broccoli.finished_description: End state: broccoli chopped into bite-sized pieces; florets about 1–2 cm with trimmed stems. Color: bright green florets, lighter green stems; surface slightly glossy if washed and patted dry. Texture: crisp and firm, clean, straight cuts. The cook may be transferring pieces to a bowl, rinsing or patting dry, and proceeding to steam, sauté, roast, or store the chopped broccoli.

chopping_scallion.progress_description: Start/in-progress: whole scallion with green tops and white bulbs yet to be fully sliced; pieces showing a mix of intact stalks and partially cut sections. Inconsistent cross-sections (rounds, half-moons, or thin shreds) and varying lengths; edges may be jagged or smooth; color remains bright green and white; surface damp from washing; knife marks visible on cut faces. The person is guiding the knife via chopping motion, pausing between cuts, and adjusting grip to keep stack stable.
chopping_scallion.finished_description: End state: scallion greens and whites are finely chopped into uniform small pieces, about 2–5 mm. The mix is bright green and white, moist but not soggy, with a crisp texture and no long stems. The cook may scoop the chopped scallions into a bowl, sprinkle them over a dish, or add them to a hot pan.

chopping_lettuce.progress_description: Start/intermediate states show a whole head or torn leaves on a cutting board; pieces range from thick shreds to coarse slivers. Colors vary from vivid green outer leaves to pale, crisp inner cores. Edges are uneven, surfaces glossy from washing, fibers visible. In progress: knife moves in slicing, chopping, or rocking motions; a hand stabilizes the lettuce while the other guides the blade; some stems or core remain intact, more pieces accumulating as work continues.
chopping_lettuce.finished_description: End state: lettuce leaves uniformly chopped into bite-sized pieces (roughly 0.5–2 cm), in ribbons or small cubes, with stems removed. Color ranges from bright green to pale green; surface slightly glossy from natural moisture. Texture: crisp-tender, no limp or wilted bits; minimal dark edges or bruising. The chopped pile sits in a bowl or on a board, ready for dressing, tossing into a salad, or transfer to storage—e.g., bagging or plating.

chopping_cauliflower.progress_description: Start or in-progress states of chopping cauliflower include: a whole head with outer leaves trimmed; florets partially separated but not diced; irregular large chunks and smaller fragments on the board; jagged cut faces exposing pale dense interior; color white to pale cream with hints of green from remaining leaves; hands grip the knife, stabilize the head, and perform a slicing or rocking motion.
chopping_cauliflower.finished_description: End state: uniform pieces of cauliflower, either bite-sized florets or small rice-like granules, 0.5–1 cm chunks or fine 2–3 mm grains. Color: white or ivory with a pale green stem trim; texture dry and crumbly, not mushy. Surfaces clean and evenly cut. The worker may rinse, measure, transfer to a bowl or sheet pan, or start cooking (sauté, steam, roast) or season.

chopping_almond.progress_description: Start/intermediate states show mixed whole almonds and irregular fragments on a cutting board. Colors range from pale tan to roasted brown with darker skins. Pieces vary from whole kernels to jagged shards, slivers, and coarse crumbs; surfaces are hard and rough-edged from chipping. Powdery almond meal may collect near small fragments. The handler uses a knife or cleaver in chopping motion, pausing to re-align pieces and apply controlled pressure as cuts proceed.
chopping_almond.finished_description: End state: chopped almonds appear as small irregular fragments, typically 1–5 mm across, with jagged edges. Color: pale tan interior, some brown skin visible. Texture: dry and crunchy, pieces loosely clumped. No whole almonds remain. The person finished chopping might be transferring them to a bowl or pan, sprinkling them into a dish, or continuing to toast or mix them into batter.

chopping_sausage.progress_description: Start: a whole sausage log or links; smooth casing, cylindrical shape, uniform pinkish red color, firm yet pliable, rounded ends. In progress: knife punctures surface with shallow crosscuts or partial slices; some segments remain attached, thickness varies, surface shows score marks, exposed interior lighter, moisture present. The chopper steadies the log on a board and uses controlled downward or rocking strokes, pausing between partial cuts.
chopping_sausage.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut sausage pieces—diced to about 5–8 mm or 1 cm chunks for slicing. Color: pinkish red with white fat flecks; texture firm and moist, with clean, straight cut surfaces; casing often visible on larger chunks. No large uncut sections; occasional residual casing or rind. The person may be heating the sausage in a pan, adding to a recipe, or tidying the board and washing the knife.

chopping_pineapple.progress_description: Start or intermediate states of chopping pineapple: a whole fruit with a spiky crown on a cutting board; skin intact or partially peeled to reveal pale yellow flesh. Knife is partially through flesh with juice beading at the cut. In-progress pieces include visible slices, wedges, or irregular chunks, with the white core sometimes exposed. The surface is moist and fibrous; hands grip and guide the knife, with rind scraps nearby.
chopping_pineapple.finished_description: End state: peeled and cored pineapple cut into uniform pieces (1–2 cm cubes or batons). Flesh is bright yellow, juicy, and firm with clean, smooth edges; skin, eyes, and core fragments removed. Pieces gathered in a bowl or tray, ready for cooking or serving. The person finished chopping might transfer them to a bowl, rinse, marinate, weigh, or store in a container for later use.

chopping_date.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: date may be whole or partially sliced. Shapes range from oval with intact skin to wedges or chunks. Skin is glossy brown; exposed flesh is amber, sticky, and fibrous, becoming softer near the center. In progress, knife marks appear along the fruit; skin may be peeled or scored but pieces are not yet fully separated. The cutter steadies the date with one hand and slices with a sharp blade, sometimes prying around the pit.
chopping_date.finished_description: End state: chopped dates in uniform small pieces, roughly 4–8 mm cubes or irregular chunks, dark brown with lighter cut surfaces; moist, pliable and slightly sticky; no whole pits visible; edges neatly cut. The pieces may cling together into a glossy mass. The person finished chopping might be transferring them to a mixing bowl, folding into batter or oats, or wiping their knife/board and preparing the next ingredient.

chopping_leek.progress_description: During leek chopping, the stalks show white to light green bases with darker green tops; surfaces damp and slightly fibrous. A knife is mid-stroke, leaving uneven, elongated slices and partial stacks along the board; some rings or shreds remain attached or loosely separated. Slices vary in width, with some longer ribbons curling near the blade. The worker's hands grip the handle, guiding the blade while applying steady pressure, keeping roots trimmed and tops intact.
chopping_leek.finished_description: End state: cleaned, trimmed leek cut into uniform pieces—finely chopped or small dice (~2–5 mm). Colors: white to pale green cores, with outer greens darker; any tops trimmed or left as ribbons. Texture: moist, translucent, ranging from tender-crisp to soft; no long fibrous strands. After chopping, the person may scoop into a bowl or pan and start sautéing or add to a recipe.

chopping_butter.progress_description: Start: a pale yellow butter block, firm or softened, with a smooth, glossy surface and rectangular edges. In progress: a knife blade mid-stroke on a cutting board; butter partially separated into irregular chunks and slivers, some still attached to the block. Shapes range from thin shards to chunky bits; sizes vary; interior pale and slightly creamy, surface sheen reflecting fat. The person presses, angles the blade, or uses a light rocking or sawing motion to cut.
chopping_butter.finished_description: End state: butter is cut into uniform pieces—small cubes or dices roughly 0.5–1 cm across—pale yellow with glistening, clean-cut faces. The surface is smooth but slightly crumbly if very cold; texture firm yet scoopable or slightly pliant if warmed. No large chunks remain. The person may transfer the chunks to a bowl, return them to the fridge, or begin melting them in a pan.

chopping_chilies.progress_description: Start or intermediate states show chilies in varying forms: whole or halved, elongated sticks, or irregular slabs. Surfaces may be glossy with moisture; skins crisp or pliant; colors range from deep green to red or orange. Edges are rough or jagged, with seeds exposed or partially split. On the board you may see cut marks, juice pooled, and pepper fragments clinging to the blade. The person’s hands steady the chili, blade mid-slice, guiding the piece onward.
chopping_chilies.finished_description: End state: chopped chilies appear as uniform or near-uniform small pieces—diced (about 2–6 mm) or finely minced—moist and glossy, with visible seeds and membranes if not fully removed. Colors range from bright green to red/orange/yellow, depending on cultivar. Surfaces are cleanly cut; no large chunks remain. The cook may transfer the pile to a bowl, wipe the board/knife, rinse, or head to the pan to start sautéing or seasoning.

chopping_capsicum.progress_description: Start: whole capsicum on a cutting board, glossy skin, stem attached, color varying by variety.
