In progress: pepper half or quarter held to the board; seeds and membranes partially removed or exposed; knife making straight or curved splits. Resulting pieces vary from long, thin strips to irregular chunks; edges show cross-sections with pale, moist interiors. Surfaces glisten with juice; skin remains vibrant; thickness and size of segments differ, indicating ongoing chopping.
chopping_capsicum.finished_description: End state: seeds and pith removed; pepper flesh divided into uniform pieces. Common forms: diced cubes (~1 cm per side) or julienne strips (~3–5 mm x 1–2 cm). Colors mirror pepper variety (green, red, yellow, orange); skin smooth, flesh crisp and moist; some pieces may be slightly curved. After chopping, the person may scoop pieces into a bowl or pan, wipe the board, or start sautéing.

chopping_olive.progress_description: Start/in-progress olives show whole fruits with knife work visible. Shapes range from intact spheres to halves, quarters, or thin cross-sections; some pits may be exposed or already removed. Colors span olive-green, olive-black, or sunlit gold, with glossy skin and pale, slightly translucent flesh. Texture varies from firm to yielding; edges may be scored or ribbed. The practitioner steadies the olive, positions fingers on the blade, and makes successive cuts or splits, rotating the fruit as needed.
chopping_olive.finished_description: End state: olives finely chopped into uniform cubes or slivers about 2–4 mm, pitted, with a glossy finish and color ranging from green to dark purple/black depending on variety and curing. Pieces are evenly sized, soft but distinct, with no whole pits. The chopped mixture is loose, slightly oily from brine; moisture shows as sheen. Next actions: the person may toss into a salad, fold into pasta sauce, or grind into a tapenade.

chopping_thyme.progress_description: Start/intermediate thyme: woody stems with clusters of tiny dark-green leaves; leaves are whole or only lightly torn, color olive to bright green; stems feel fibrous, slightly dry. In progress: knife presses through the herb, leaves prying away from stems; some fragments or torn leaf edges lie loose; bits may still cling to short stem portions. The person holds the knife, guiding with the other hand, using chopping or rocking motions to separate leaf from stem.
chopping_thyme.finished_description: End state: finely minced thyme with uniform leaf fragments, about 1 to 2 mm, and no visible woody stems. Color bright to olive green; the chopped mass is delicate, crumbly to slightly moist, not chunky. Surface is fine and even, aroma strong. After chopping, the person typically gathers and sprinkles the thyme over a dish or into a pan, then resumes cooking (sauteing, simmering) or cleans the board and knife.

grilling_chicken.progress_description: During grilling, chicken pieces sit on a hot grill, typically bone-in or boneless shapes; surfaces are pale pink or translucent with a glossy moisture layer; edges may curl; signs of searing appear as light brown, with faint grill marks; juices bead on the surface; some pieces are moved or flipped for even contact, spacing adjusted.
grilling_chicken.finished_description: End state: chicken pieces fully cooked with opaque white interior and no pink near the bone; juices run clear or slightly milky. Exterior golden-brown with distinct grill marks, crisp edges, and a light char. Size may shrink slightly due to shrinkage; surface moisture present but not pooling. The cook rests the meat briefly, then plates or slices it for serving.

grilling_steak.progress_description: Start state: raw steak, 1–2 inches thick, red-pink interior visible; surface moist, fat edges glossy. In progress: surface browns and sears; grill marks appear; juices bead and steam; edges curl; fat renders; moisture loss shrinks size slightly. The cook sears, flips with tongs, adjusts heat, and may baste briefly, monitoring time and surface color.
grilling_steak.finished_description: End state: a rested steak with a well-seared crust, uniform mahogany-brown surface and distinct grill marks. Exterior crust crisp, interior doneness matching the target (rare to medium-well): pink to brown center, with juices visibly pooling or shimmering when cut. Thickness slightly reduced—about original thickness minus a bit from cooking; edges cooked through, fat rendered. The cook is likely resting the steak on a plate or cutting board, tented with foil, then slicing or plating.

grilling_corn.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: ears still often with husks or partly peeled; kernels pale yellow or white, firm and glossy, remaining intact. As grilling begins, husks loosen or peel back; surface moisture beads, kernels soften and become slightly translucent. Light browning along tips and some gentle grill marks appear. The cook rotates the ears, moves them closer to or away from heat, and sometimes baste with oil or butter to promote even cooking.
grilling_corn.finished_description: End state: ears about 7–9 inches long; husks removed or peeled back. Kernels plump, uniform, bright yellow to golden, with blistered, lightly charred spots and a bit of caramelization. Surface glossy from melted butter or oil; texture tender with a slight snap. Smoky-sweet aroma. The cook uses tongs to remove the corn from the grill, rests briefly, then serves or baste/season before eating.

grilling_fish.progress_description:
Start: Raw or thawed fish fillet or whole fish; skin on or off; curved shape, uneven thickness; flesh translucent pinkish or pale; surface moisture and tiny ice crystals.

In progress: On a hot grill, sizzle heard; surface sears with faint marks; outer edges turn opaque while center remains translucent; juices bead; fat renders; cook flips and moves for even contact, adjusts heat.
grilling_fish.finished_description: End state: an evenly cooked fillet is opaque through, flakes readily with a fork, and stays moist. The shape is mostly intact but slightly contracted; size is modestly reduced by shrinkage. Exterior shows a golden-brown sear or crust with grill marks; flesh color ranges from white to light pink/gray depending on species. Aim for 63°C (145°F) internally. The cook rests briefly, then plates and serves.

grilling_pineapple.progress_description: On a hot grill, pineapple is cut into rings or wedges (thick/thin), placed with space between. Flesh is pale yellow to golden, still glossy with juice; surface shows initial browning and faint diagonal grill marks; edges may soften but hold shape; skin remains on some varieties or removed. Natural sugars start caramelizing; small moisture bubbles appear. The cook uses tongs to rotate, brush with oil, and maintain even exposure.
grilling_pineapple.finished_description: End state: pineapple slices or chunks display golden brown caramelization with distinct grill marks; surfaces glazed and slightly charred at edges, shape remaining as original while edges may curl, moisture retained but softened in the core. Color ranges from warm yellow to amber; size may shrink as juices reduce. Texture is tender yet pleasantly firm with a crisp exterior. The cook is removing the pieces with tongs, resting briefly, then plating or glazing for service.

grilling_salmon.progress_description:
Start/intermediate salmon grilling state (in progress):
- Fillet or portion, skin-on, ~1–2 in thick; raw pink-orange flesh with translucent edges.
- Surface sizzles; moisture beads; fat striations visible; steam rises.
- Grill marks begin; edges curl slightly; center remains soft and still translucent.
- Cook uses tongs to flip, reposition, baste lightly, and adjust heat to prevent sticking.
grilling_salmon.finished_description: End state: a salmon fillet with a golden-brown crust and visible grill marks; edges may curl slightly. The interior is opaque pink-orange and flakes easily, with a moist, firm texture. Typical size is ~6–8 inches long, ~1 inch thick. After removing from heat, rest 2–5 minutes, then plate with lemon and herbs, or cut into portions.

grilling_onion.progress_description: Start/early stage: onion pieces (rings or wedges) arranged on grill. Shapes remain recognizable; edges begin to soften. Color shifts from raw to translucent pale gold; moisture beads appear; surface glistens with oil. Texture transitions from crisp to tender; slight curling at edges; intermittent grill marks. Sizzling sound and steam rising indicate heat contact. The cook moves pieces with tongs, rotates, and spreads to avoid crowding; maintains moderate heat, checks for even contact.
grilling_onion.finished_description: End state: onion slices are soft and translucent with caramelized, golden-brown edges; grill marks may be visible and a few bits charred. They’re tender and jammy, size reduced from moisture loss but still in rings or wedges. Color ranges from pale yellow to deep amber/brown. The person finished with grilling onion might be removing them from the grill, transferring to a plate, or sautéing briefly another dish and using them as a topping.

grilling_bread.progress_description:
- Start: Rectangular bread slice on a hot grill; shape unchanged; surface pale and dry; edges intact.
- Early contact: Grill ridges imprint; light sheen of moisture; corners may lift.
- Mid-progress: Pale tan patches appear; some grill marks; crumb still soft to touch; steam visible.
- Handling: Cook rotates slice with tongs; presses gently for even contact; checks underside.
- Additional slices: Spacing allows air; bread may buckle slightly.
grilling_bread.finished_description: End state: bread slices grilled to golden-brown, with crisp edges and evenly toasted surfaces; exterior dry, interior tender, and visible grill marks. Slices stay roughly their original size and shape, flat and rectangular or oblong, sometimes puffed slightly. A light butter sheen may appear if butter was used. The person is removing, buttering, stacking, or cutting the slices to serve.

grilling_tomato.progress_description: During grilling, in-progress tomato states include: whole fruit with blistering skin, slight cracking, and a glossy surface from juice; slight shrinkage as moisture evaporates; color deepens but remains red; faint grill lines. If halved, cut faces darken at edges and areas around seeds soften and glisten. The cook rotates with tongs, checks underside, lifts to inspect, and adjusts distance to heat, possibly pressing lightly to test yield.
grilling_tomato.finished_description: End state: a tomato half or slice with charred, blistered skin; flesh softened to a tender, slightly mushy center; slight shrinkage from moisture loss; color deep red to orange with dark grill lines; juices released and concentrated at the edges; seeds/pulp exposed but still cohesive. The cook is likely lifting it off the grill, resting briefly, and then slicing or chopping for serving (burger topping, pasta, bruschetta).

grilling_zucchini.progress_description: Start or intermediate states: zucchini on the grill as whole, halved, rounds, or spears. Skin remains bright green; flesh pale and firm; edges may begin to soften. Moisture beads, steam releases, and light sizzle occurs. A glaze of oil glints on the surface; faint grill marks emerge. The cook brushes oil, sprinkles seasoning, and flips or rearranges pieces for even contact, watching texture progress.
grilling_zucchini.finished_description: End state: zucchini slices or spears with dark grill marks, green skin with browned edges; shrunk slightly in length; exterior caramelized and tender-crisp inside, juicy and softly yielding. Color ranges from bright green to pale brown where seared. They may be plated with a drizzle of oil or herbs. The cook is likely removing from heat, transferring to a plate, tasting, sprinkling salt/pepper, or plating for serving.

grilling_asparagus.progress_description: At the start, asparagus stalks are bright green and rigid, with trimmed pale ends and compact tips; sizes range from slim to thick. Surfaces are smooth, sometimes glossy from oil. In progress, spears lie on the grate, sizzle and steam rising; tips remain relatively firm while spears begin to soften and deepen in color. Light browning or early grill marks appear where they contact heat as the cook rotates them with tongs.
grilling_asparagus.finished_description: End state: asparagus spears bright green with brown grill marks and blistered spots; tips tender, stalks firm yet tender-crisp (al dente); outer skin slightly wrinkled but not mushy; moisture present with a light oil gloss. Spears evenly sized, ends trimmed, arranged on a plate. The cook, finished grilling, rests the grill, then serves, often with a drizzle of lemon or olive oil and a dusting of salt/pepper or parmesan.

grilling_bacon.progress_description: At the start, thin bacon strips lie flat in a pan, pale pink with translucent fat. As heat builds, edges may curl and the surface glistens as fat begins to render. The strip remains pliable, with white fat streaks and pink meat visible. Bubbles form where fat meets the pan, and moisture pools in places. The cook uses tongs or a spatula to shift, rotate, and monitor progress without declaring completion.
grilling_bacon.finished_description: End state: bacon strips are browned to golden-amber with darker edges, curling or bending slightly; the surface is rendered and slightly glossy with fat, becoming crisp or chewy depending on time; some shrinkage shortens length, width varies, and edges may be crisp with a frilled look. Color ranges pale to deep brown; texture: crisp around edges, tender center. When done, the cook uses tongs to lift strips, drains on paper towels, then plates or serves, while the pan cools.

grilling_eggplant.progress_description: Start/int: Whole eggplant, 6–8 inches long, oblong, glossy deep-purple skin, firm yet yield to fingertip. Halves or rounds: cream-colored flesh with tiny seeds. In progress: skin blistering and wrinkling, some translucence near cut sides; oil sheen on surface; grill marks beginning to form as ridges; moisture beads on surface; pieces turned with tongs, rotated for even contact, brushed with oil or seasoning.
grilling_eggplant.finished_description: End state: eggplant pieces are tender and creamy inside. Slices show golden-brown, blistered skin with crisp grill marks; whole small eggplants are soft with charred skin. Flesh is pale, moist, and slightly oily from surface coating. Shapes depend on cut (disks, wedges, or halves). The cook may be removing them from the grill, resting briefly, then slicing or serving, perhaps with salt, oil, or a finishing sauce.

grilling_shrimp.progress_description: Start/intermediate grilling shrimp: raw, thawed, with shells and tails on or off. Flesh is translucent gray to blue, slick with surface moisture, size uniform; shrimp may be curled slightly and appear raw in the center. As grilling proceeds: edges turn pink or light orange and the flesh becomes increasingly opaque from outside in; surface glistens with oil or marinade; shrinkage may occur; texture stays pliable, with occasional grill marks as the cook flips, baste, or sears.
grilling_shrimp.finished_description: End state: shrimp are opaque pink-white with a hint of orange, uniformly cooked, firm yet tender, and slightly smaller due to moisture loss, with a resilient bite. Exterior shows light sear marks and caramelization; shells (if left on) pinkish-red; tails darken. Shrimp curl into a distinct C shape. No translucence in the center. The cook is likely removing them from the grill, transferring to a plate, and possibly dabbing with butter/lemon or letting them rest.

grilling_sausage.progress_description: At the start, sausages are plump, pale pink-gray with a moist surface inside casing. As grilling progresses, casings tighten, sausages lengthen slightly and curve, beads of fat form on the surface. The exterior shows light browning and developing grill marks; juices bead and sizzle. You’ll see steam and minor flare-ups. The cook uses tongs to rotate and reposition, adjust heat, and monitor color, sometimes lifting to glimpse the interior.
grilling_sausage.finished_description: End state: sausages are browned and caramelized, with crisp, blistered casings and clear grill marks. The interior is fully cooked (internal temp about 71–74°C / 160–165°F), opaque and juicy, with slight shrinkage. They retain an elongated cylindrical shape, sometimes curved. The person finished grilling may remove them with tongs, let them rest briefly, and then plate or serve—often in buns or sliced for plating.

grilling_cheese.progress_description: Raw to mid-melt cheese on a hot grill. Shape is still rectangular or slightly deformed from handling; thickness roughly the same, around 1/4 inch. Color remains pale ivory to pale yellow, with a glossy, translucent edge forming as fat/oil renders. Surface may show small bubbles and steam; edges start to soften and begin to melt into the pan, grill marks appearing. The cook watches, slides a spatula under, and occasionally presses or flips to distribute heat.
grilling_cheese.finished_description: End state: grilled cheese shows a golden-brown crust with grill marks; outer edge crisp, interior warm and either soft or fully melted (depending on cheese). Shape usually matches the slice (rectangular or round); thickness about 0.5 to 1 cm. Colors range from pale gold to deep caramel. If melted, surface is glossy and stretchy. The person is likely removing from the grill, flipping, slicing, or plating and serving.

grilling_potato.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: potato pieces—wedges, slices, or cubes—are pale, opaque, and firm with smooth or uneven skin. Sizes vary (roughly 1–2 inches). As grilling progresses, surfaces show light browning, translucent edges, and occasional charring or blistering; moisture beads form and steam escapes; interiors remain relatively firm with a softening core forming. The cook oils or seasons the surfaces, spaces pieces evenly, and flips or rotates them for even heat distribution, lid on or off as needed.
grilling_potato.finished_description: End state: potatoes cooked through with a crisp exterior. Pieces (wedges, slices, or cubes) are golden to deep brown, with distinct grill marks and caramelized edges. Inside is tender and fluffy; moisture reduced. Size remains as cut, shape largely intact but edges crisp. The cook, finished, removes from grill with tongs, rests briefly, then plates and may season or top with butter, herbs, or sauce.

grilling_pepper.progress_description: On grill, peppers show early blistering and patchy skin darkening. Whole peppers or slices shrink, edges wrinkle, and grill lines appear. Colors shift from bright green to olive or yellow/orange with translucent, glistening flesh. Skin bubbles and lifts as moisture escapes; seeds loosen but remain inside. Steam escapes from vents; juices bead. The cook uses tongs or a spatula, rotates pieces, and monitors softness, blistering, and color change to control progress.
grilling_pepper.finished_description: End state: peppers blistered and charred on the skin, with blackened patches and wrinkled, softened flesh. They’ve shrunk slightly; color deepens—green to olive, or red/yellow becomes darker. Exterior glistens with oil; interior flesh is tender and pale. After grilling: the cook rests, transfers peppers to a bowl, covers or steams to loosen skins, then peels, seeds, and dices as needed.

blending_banana.progress_description: In start or intermediate frames, banana pieces appear as jagged chunks (5–15 mm) with some crushed fibers. Colors range from bright yellow to tan, with oxidation specks. Textures span fibrous chunks to a loose, wet slurry; liquid pools and a glossy surface forms. Blades rotate, creating swirls and bubbles along the walls. The person may be pulsing the blender, adding more fruit, or scraping the sides between bursts.
blending_banana.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous banana puree with no visible chunks. The color ranges from bright yellow to light tan, often slightly browned from ripening. Consistency varies from thick and spoonable to pourable depending on added liquid; surface is glossy and may show a fine foam. In final frames, the person pours the mixture into a bowl or measuring cup, then scrapes the blender and cleans up, proceeding with batter, smoothie, or recipe.

blending_egg.progress_description: At the start, yolk and white often stay separate: yolk round, glossy; whites translucent or milky. As blending begins, droplets range from tiny to larger, swirl, and the mixture lightens to pale yellow or grayish, with threads or ribbons. Bubbles form, surface foams at the whisk tips, and the liquid thickens from runny to slightly viscous. Whisking involves circular or back-and-forth strokes, pausing to scrape the bowl, and occasional splashes to the sides.
blending_egg.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous liquid with pale yellow color; no chunks or shell fragments, uniform texture, and a slight surface foam. The volume is increased from added air; the mix is pourable to thinly viscous. It has no defined shape and flows. The person might now pour it into a pan to scramble or fry an omelet, or fold it into batter.

blending_tomato.progress_description: Start: whole or quartered tomatoes with skins and seeds, bright red, wet surface. Early blend: chunks break into coarse pulp; skins and seeds still identifiable; color uneven with pinkish streaks; some juice escapes. Mid-blend: mixture becomes chunky slurry; fibers suspended; surface foams; blades churn with a hum. Person actions: loading tomatoes, pulsing or blending, occasionally scraping sides, adjusting speed, watching texture evolve.
blending_tomato.finished_description: End state: a smooth, uniform tomato purée with no large chunks; seeds/skin largely integrated, leaving micro-specks. Color is consistent red to orange-red; glossy surface; medium-thick, pourable viscosity. The product is a homogeneous liquid or sauce. After blending, the person may stop the blender, remove the lid, scrape the sides, and transfer the purée to a bowl or pot, then stir, season, or refrigerate.

blending_strawberry.progress_description: Starting/partially blended strawberries display whole berries or large chunks, stems often present. Color ranges from vivid red to pink; some pieces show white cores. Texture is chunky or pulpy, with visible juice and occasional bubbles near the blades. Actions by the person include pulsing or low-speed blending, adding a splash of liquid, and using a spatula to nudge contents or scrape the sides while checking texture.
blending_strawberry.finished_description: End state: a uniform pink-red strawberry puree or smoothie base. No large chunks; seeds may be barely visible. Shape/size: a smooth mass rather than discrete pieces. Color is homogeneous; texture ranges from pourable liquid to thick, spoonable puree; often glossy and slightly frothy, sometimes strained to remove seeds. The person finished blending may be pouring into a glass, serving as a smoothie, pouring over yogurt/ice cream, or scraping the blender for cleanup.

blending_garlic.progress_description: At the start, whole garlic cloves with papery skins appear, unprocessed and uneven in size. As blending begins, pieces break into irregular shards, some quarter-sized, others minced flecks; color pale ivory to light tan; surfaces look dry at first, then glistening with released juices. The blender blades spin in bursts, cups rattle, and the user presses pulse or runs a low speed. Skins may loosen and drift within the container as mixing proceeds.
blending_garlic.finished_description: End state: garlic is transformed into a pale cream paste or fine mash. Color ranges from off-white to light tan; texture is thick, spreadable, smooth or with tiny, uniform granules; surface may be glossy if oil is included; no visible whole cloves. If chopped to paste, minor air pockets. The person is likely scraping the blender, stopping blades, and spooning/spreading the paste into a bowl or pan, maybe rinsing off blades or washing hands.

blending_butter.progress_description: Start: butter blocks or sticks, cold and firm, edges crisp, color pale yellow to white, rectangular pieces varying in size. During blending: pieces soften at the edges, surface becomes glossy, some chunks remain distinct, small air pockets form, creamy-looking streaks appear as fat and moisture begin to combine. Texture is uneven: partly solid, partly pasty. Tools: spatula scraping bowl sides; hands or mixer blades mix, push, mash, or rotate to induce contact and breakup clumps.
blending_butter.finished_description: End state: smooth, homogeneous, whipped butter. Uniform pale yellow to ivory color, glossy surface, light, airy texture with tiny air pockets. Consistency is spreadable and soft, yet scoopable, with no lumps or grain. When done, the person stops blending, scrapes the bowl and blades, and transfers the whipped butter to a container or parchment paper, shaping into a disk or log, then chill or serve as a spread.

blending_oat.progress_description: Start: dry oats—pale, flat flakes, oblong pieces, matte. In progress: blades whirl; oats crack into smaller specks, chunks still visible; powdery dust rises; sporadic bubbles and a glossy sheen appear as liquid swirls; texture is grainy and lumpy, with pockets of partial puree. The person pulses, nudges oats toward the blades, and occasionally stops to scrape the jar walls.
blending_oat.finished_description: End state: a homogeneous, pale beige slurry with no visible whole oats. Oat particles are finely milled; texture ranges from milk-like to thick paste, depending on water ratio. Color is light, creamy beige; surface is smooth and glossy. If strained, it yields oat milk; if not, a pulpy but smooth oatmeal slurry remains. The person may pour into a jar, strain, cook into milk, or rinse the blender.

blending_sugar.progress_description: Initial state shows discrete sugar granules—white with translucent edges—settled or resting in the bowl. As blending starts, grains clump where moisture or fat meets sugar; some crystals begin to dissolve, creating grainy, uneven texture. Movement creates visible swirls, streaks, and bubbles; the color shifts from pure white to slightly off-white. The operator stirs or switches on the blender, then periodically scrapes the bowl’s sides to mix remaining pockets.
blending_sugar.finished_description: End state: Sugar ground to a fine, uniform powder (powdered/confectioners’ sugar). Particles are tiny, irregular grains with a silky, flour-like texture; color is bright white to pale ivory, often with a hint of starchiness from anti-caking agents. It should flow freely, without visible clumps. After blending, the person might sift or measure the powder, transfer it to a bowl or container, or scrape and clean the blender.

blending_milk.progress_description: Start or mid-blend, milk is a moving, opaque white with visible streaks where fat and water have not yet mixed fully. Early foam or bubbles form on the surface; color can vary from milky white to grayish where air is entrained. Incomplete blend shows irregular blobs, lumps, grainy texture, or thin films; viscosity is uneven. The person might pulse the blender, scrape the sides, tilt the container, or gradually adjust speed as they monitor progress.
blending_milk.finished_description: End state: a uniform, pale-white liquid with fine, evenly dispersed air bubbles. Surface is smooth and slightly glossy; no separation or curdling. Viscosity is a touch higher than plain milk, sometimes resembling light cream; if aeration was strong, a thin cap of microfoam may crown the top. The mixture pours steadily and holds a slight sheen. After blending, the person might pour it into a cup, taste, or rinse the blender.

blending_ice.progress_description: At the start, whole ice cubes or crushed pieces circulate as frosty white chunks. During blending, fragments break into shards, icy slivers, and a cloudy slurry; surfaces glitter with moisture. The mix appears heterogeneous: intact cubes, broken fragments, slush forming at the bottom. The tempo of motion and blade noise increases as the ice is pulsed; the operator may add liquid, scrape sides, pause to adjust speed, or tilt the container to rebalance shards.
blending_ice.finished_description: End state: finely crushed ice resembling snow or granular slush—particles small (rice- to pea-sized or finer), white to cloudy translucent, very moist and slightly porous; texture ranges from fluffy to slightly compacted, often forming a loose mound or wet slurry. After blending, the person might turn off the blender, remove the lid, scoop or pour the slush into a glass or container, and clean the blender and surrounding area.

blending_onion.progress_description: At the start, you see separate onion pieces: rings, cubes, or wedges, white with purple skins, moisture on the surface; sizes vary from tiny to several millimeters. During progress, chunks break down, surfaces become shiny and slightly translucent, juices mingle, and the mixture remains chunky with uneven specks. The person pulses the blender, stops to scrape the container, and adjusts onion quantity, blending in short bursts.
blending_onion.finished_description: End state: a uniform onion puree or fine paste. Particles are tiny (often under 2 mm) with no large chunks. Color is pale to translucent white or light yellow (red onions yield a pinkish tint). Texture ranges from smooth to slightly gritty, but cohesive and pourable. After blending, the person is likely sautéing it in oil or butter as a base, deglazing a pan, or adding it to sauces/soups; or refrigerating for later use.

blending_date.progress_description: At the outset or mid-process, date pieces are chunky and irregular, ranging from small shreds to larger fragments. Colors vary from tan to deep brown; the paste is gritty or fibrous, with partly emulsified zones and streaks of liquid. The surface may be glossy where oils release, or frothy from air. In a blender, blades spin while unmixed bits cling to sides; you might see scraping, pulses, or additions of water or oil to aid blending.
blending_date.finished_description: End state: a smooth, uniform date paste—no chunks—with creamy to thick consistency, color from light amber to dark brown, glossy surface, occupying the blender jar or container as a uniform mass. Post-blend actions: they may scrape with a spatula, transfer to a jar, taste for sweetness, or clean the blender and lid.

blending_cashew.progress_description: In early to mid-blend, cashews appear as mixed sizes: whole kernels, halved pieces, and broken shards. Texture is grainy with visible chunks; color is uneven beige with oil sheen around some pieces. Surfaces show blade marks and uneven streaks. Small clumps form and break apart as mixing continues. The person may pulse the blender, scrape the jar sides with a spatula, and add tiny amounts of oil or water while checking texture.
blending_cashew.finished_description: End state: a smooth, uniform cashew paste or butter. Nuts ground to a paste with small to no lumps; texture creamy and spreadable; color pale ivory to light tan; glossy finish; consistency varies from thick, spoonable to pourable when thinned with water or oil; surface appears glossy and uniform; few tiny specks if under-blended. Post-blend actions: scrape the sides, stop blender, transfer to jar or bowl, and taste or adjust with salt, water, or oil.

blending_sauce.progress_description: During blending, sauce appears in motion with partial emulsions: oil slicks on top, opaque chunks visible, and color patches where ingredients remain unmixed. The texture ranges from thick to loose, with bubbles and foamy rims along the blade sweep. Side walls may show scraped residuals. The operator pauses to scrape with a spatula, tweaks blade speed, and adds liquid or solids gradually, observing texture changes as blending continues.
blending_sauce.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous sauce with uniform color and sheen, no lumps; a pourable yet spoon-coating viscosity that forms a thin film on utensils; glossy surface, small air bubbles may be present. The sauce should flow in a steady stream from a spoon or pitcher. The person has turned off the blender and is pouring or transferring to a jar or pot, then tasting, adjusting, or cleaning.

blending_almond.progress_description: In the initial frame, whole almonds—peeled or with skins—sit in a container, varying in shape and size with matte tan exteriors. As blending begins, jagged fragments appear; shards whirl with grinding dust. Midway, a coarse meal forms, with granules of different sizes and a faint oil sheen on surfaces. The person operates the blender, pausing to scrape the sides and pulse or adjust speed.
blending_almond.finished_description: End state: the almonds appear fully homogenized; discrete chunks are gone. Texture ranges from fine almond flour (soft, powdery, sand-like) to ultra-smooth almond butter (creamy, glossy, spoonable). Color is light tan to golden brown, depending on roast and fat content; surface may gleam slightly. The mixture is cohesive with no gritty particles. The person may be scraping the blender, transferring to a jar, continuing to blend, adding oil, salt, or sweeteners, or using in a recipe.

blending_cheese.progress_description: Early to mid-blend visuals show scattered cheese chunks and shredded pieces dispersed in a partial emulsion. Sizes range from fine shreds to chunky cubes. Colors pale ivory to yellow; specks of herbs or pepper. The texture is inconsistent: sticky, tacky, slightly stringy, with some melted edges and moisture separation. The person may pulse, scrape the bowl, adjust speed, or drizzle a liquid into the mix.
blending_cheese.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous cheese mixture with no lumps or shards; uniform color (pale yellow to creamy orange, depending on blend); glossy, velvety texture; consistency ranges from pourable to spreadable as heat and emulsion dictate; no separated fat. The blender is off; the person may scrape the sides, taste, adjust seasoning, and transfer to a sauce, dip, or topping for macaroni, nachos, or sandwiches.

blending_mango.progress_description: Early or mid-blend mango shows visible chunks: bright orange-yellow cubes and irregular wedges, some pieces still intact. Surfaces are glossy and damp; moisture beads between chunks. There are color streaks where pulp hasn’t mixed, with patches of unblended fiber. Texture ranges from firm to slightly mashed, with small air bubbles. The person pulses, stirs, and uses a spatula to scrape the sides, pressing fruit toward the blades and continuing mixing.
blending_mango.finished_description: End state: mango puree—smooth, uniform orange with no large chunks; texture ranges from thick to pourable, often with fine airiness and occasional tiny fibrous bits; color bright orange to amber; aroma sweet mango; temperature varies. Post-blend actions: pouring into a measuring cup or bowl, tasting and adjusting sweetness/acid (lime juice), pouring into a glass or serving dish, and cleaning the blender/jar.

blending_cream.progress_description: Start: cream sits in a chilled bowl as a pale, liquid base. As blending begins, you see slow swirls and ribbons, air bubbles rising, and a glossy surface. Edges may cling to the whisk, creating faint streaks and scraper marks on the bowl. The texture remains runny to thick, with uneven viscosity and tiny lumps where fat hasn’t fully incorporated. The person whisking or blending moves the utensil, occasionally scraping the sides to reintroduce unmixed cream.
blending_cream.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous mass with no visible separation. Shape or footprint is a soft spread or cohesive mound; surface remains even, usually glossy. Color is uniform, matching the base cream; no streaks. Consistency ranges from spreadable paste to light whipped foam, depending on processing; viscosity is moderate. After blending, the user may apply it to skin, spread it on a surface, or transfer it and continue to pat, buff, or set with tools.

blending_pepper.progress_description: At the start/intermediate stage, pepper particles are mixed: whole peppercorns, broken pieces, and a fine dust. Shapes vary from spheres to irregular shards; sizes range from coarse grains to fine particles. Colors span black, white, green, and red, depending on variety. Textures go from glossy to rough, with matte surfaces. The mass looks loose, with visible pepper dust on the surface. The grinder is being twisted, pepper fed in, and lightly tapped to settle.
blending_pepper.finished_description: End state: pepper is ground into fine to coarse particles—uniform micro-particles, typically under 1 mm (often 0.2–0.5 mm for a medium grind). Color ranges from dark charcoal to black; surface is usually matte with a slight oily sheen from essential oils. If blended wet, it forms a smooth paste; dry blends yield a dry, free-flowing powder. After blending, the person may transfer to a jar, wipe the blade, or taste.

blending_avocado.progress_description: At blend start/early stages, avocado in a bowl appears as uneven chunks; many pieces still intact, some lightly mashed. Colors show bright green, olive, and skin flecks, with a glossy but mottled surface. Texture is coarse, with ridges and pockets of liquid; texture remains inconsistent. The blender blades may be visible in motion; the person pulses, scoops, and presses with a spatula or fork, inspecting texture from the sides.
blending_avocado.finished_description: End state: a uniform avocado puree with no chunks; color bright to pale green, sometimes with a yellow tint near the surface. Texture ranges from smooth to creamy, occasionally slightly chunky if blending was short. Consistency is spoonable or pourable. Shape is amorphous in a bowl or a dollop on a surface. The person is likely transferring the puree to a bowl, seasoning it (lime, salt), or spreading/whisking into guacamole, dressing, or toast, and cleaning blender.

blending_ginger.progress_description: Start: ginger root with brown skin, peeled into irregular chunks; pale yellow flesh; sizes vary; fibrous. Intermediate: blades whirl; fibers shred into irregular granules, some strands still visible; moisture release yields a wet, gritty mix; tiny bubbles form, sides coated with shreds. The operator pulses, taps the jar, and scrapes the sides with a spatula, adding water as needed.
blending_ginger.finished_description: End state: a pale golden ginger paste, color from light tan to yellow, smooth to slightly gritty, with tiny fibrous specks; thick and spreadable unless diluted. If blended with liquid, it becomes a thin, uniform ginger juice or slurry. The person finishing blending might scrape the blades, transfer the paste to a bowl, and whisk it into a sauce or marinade, or strain for juice.

blending_coconut.progress_description: Early in blending, coconut flesh appears pale white, moist chunks with skin removed; pieces range from cubes to shreds, shapes irregular. As blending proceeds, fibrous strands break into finer bits; the mix becomes a coarse, grainy slurry with pale, slightly cloudy liquid. Foam may form at the surface. The blender hums; the operator stirs with a spatula, adds small amounts of water, and guides pieces toward the blades while monitoring texture.
blending_coconut.finished_description: End state: a pale, creamy coconut mass, uniform texture with minimal visible chunks; color ranges from white to ivory to light tan. When blended with little water, a thick paste; with more water, a milky liquid or smooth coconut milk. A thin oil sheen and small air bubbles may be present. The person might scrape and empty the blender, then strain, pour, or refrigerate the mixture.

roasting_pepper.progress_description: During roasting, peppers remain whole or halved, with glossy, blistering skins and bright flesh. Surfaces pucker as heat loosens the skin; patches darken and steam escapes. The pepper stays firm yet softens gradually, seeds still attached, stem intact. The roaster uses tongs to rotate, adjust the flame, and move peppers around the grill, watching for even blistering as progress continues.
roasting_pepper.finished_description: End-state: peppers are heavily blistered and charred on the skins; most skins are blackened or easily peeled. The flesh beneath is soft, pliable, and smoky, shrinking a bit and sometimes wrinkled. Colors range from deep red/orange to blackened gray, depending on variety. Seeds loosened, juices pooled. The person typically transfers them to a bowl to steam, then peels, deseeds, and purées.

roasting_peanut.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Raw peanuts (in shell or shelled) appear pale beige; shells are smooth or slightly wrinkled, size small to medium. As roasting starts, kernels inside may swell, becoming plump and slightly rounded; surfaces gain a faint oil sheen, skins may crack or loosen; color remains pale to light tan, moisture escapes as faint steam. The roaster shakes or stirs the pan, adjusts heat, and monitors a timer or thermometer to regulate the process.
roasting_peanut.finished_description: End state: roasted peanuts are golden-brown to dark tan, dry and crisp to the bite. Kernels are plump and uniform; skins may loosen or peel, sometimes leaving a light sheen from surface oil. In-shell peanuts show cracked, warm shells. Aroma is deep, nutty. After roasting, the person often cools the batch on a rack, then salting or seasoning, and transfers to jars or bags, or proceeds to grind or package.

roasting_garlic.progress_description: Start/intermediate roasting shows whole garlic bulbs with papery skin intact or peeled cloves in a pan, color pale white to beige; cloves firm and compact. As heating proceeds, skins loosen, cloves soften and become slightly translucent; a light oil sheen appears on surfaces; aroma grows. The cook may trim tops, rub with oil and salt, wrap in foil, and place in the oven or pan, monitoring and turning as needed.
roasting_garlic.finished_description: End state: a whole roasted garlic bulb becomes very soft; cloves emerge as translucent, tender, jammy paste. Outer skin darkens or browns lightly, remaining papery and easy to peel. Cloves vary from light golden to deep amber; texture is creamy, spreadable, almost silky, with minimal bite. Aroma is caramelized and nutty. The cook may squeeze the cloves from their skins, mash into butter or paste, or fold into dishes.

roasting_tomato.progress_description: Starting tomatoes are whole or halved, of varied size, firm to the touch, with smooth, glossy skin and intact cores. In early stages, halves lie on a sheet, cut sides bright, seeds visible, surface moisture beads. As roasting begins, skins tighten and faint wrinkling appears at the edges, while aromas rise. The cook preheats the oven, oils and seasons the pieces, and sets them on a tray, turning them for even exposure.
roasting_tomato.finished_description: End state: Roasted tomatoes are blistered and collapsed slightly; skins split and may char at edges. Flesh is soft, jammy, and juicy, with reduced moisture; color deep red to mahogany, sometimes blackened patches. Seeds exposed; surface glistens with released juices. The person finished with roasting tomatoes might be removing from heat, cooling, peeling skins, and puréeing or straining into a sauce, or draining and chopping for use in dishes.

roasting_eggplant.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Eggplants can be whole or halved with the stem attached. Skin is deep purple, may be glossy or dull; size roughly unchanged. As roasting progresses, skin dulls and blisters, patches turn olive-brown, and surface wrinkles appear. Cut surfaces show glistening moisture and visible seeds; flesh remains fairly firm. The roaster often rotates with tongs, pricks or tests with a fork, adjusts flame, and applies oil or cover to heat through.
roasting_eggplant.finished_description: End state: eggplant pieces are shrunken with blistered, charred skin; color dark brown to black on the surface, flesh pale yellow-brown inside. Flesh is very soft, creamy and mashable, with most moisture released and seeds barely perceptible. The flesh may be drained or rested to remove liquid. The cook is peeling away charred skin and scooping the flesh for mashing, baba ganoush, or using as a puree.

roasting_potato.progress_description: Start: whole potatoes or cut wedges/chunks; shapes vary from rounds to sticks, sizes from bite-sized to palm-sized. Surfaces pale ivory to light tan; skin visible or peeled. Oil sheen and salt crystals glisten; cut edges may be translucent. Texture appears firm yet yieldable; moisture beads on the surface; light steam rises. In progress: pieces laid in a single layer, tossed to coat, and periodically turned for even exposure to heat.
roasting_potato.finished_description: End state: potatoes uniformly cut (wedges or chunks) with crisp, golden-brown skins and caramelized edges. Inside should be tender and fluffy, not chalky, with evenly sized pieces. Exterior crackles when pressed; slight oil sheen. Color ranges from light gold to deep bronze. Aroma of roasted starch. The cook typically removes the tray, rests briefly, then seasons and plates or serves directly.

roasting_coconut.progress_description: At the start, coconut pieces are pale white, moist, and solid—shreds or chunks of white flesh with coarse, fibrous edges inside a shell or on a tray. In progress, surfaces dry, edges curl or blister, moisture evaporates, and oils bead on the surface. Heat source (pan, oven, or flame) is active; the person stirs, flips, or shakes the tray, while pieces move and cluster as they toast.
roasting_coconut.finished_description:
End state: toasted coconut appears as golden-to-medium brown flakes or chips, dry and crisp, evenly colored, with a nutty aroma. Edges may be caramelized; avoid burnt spots.

After finishing: the person is cooling on a rack, then transferring to a bowl or jar, or grinding into flakes or powder for use.

roasting_onion.progress_description: Start (initial state): peeled onions, cut into wedges or rings, with dry, crisp outer skins; pieces of uniform size, raw and firm. In progress: in an oven or pan, oil sizzling; edges turning translucent, moisture released, surfaces glossy; colors pale to light yellow; pieces softening. Steam visible, occasional browning on exposed spots. The cook might spread, flip, toss, and monitor the tray, adjusting heat or position.
roasting_onion.finished_description: End state: roasted onions are tender and collapse under gentle pressure; color ranges from translucent amber to deep golden-brown with caramelized edges; moisture is reduced and surfaces appear glossy and jammy; whole onions flatten and shrink slightly as moisture evaporates; sliced onions sag and curl, sometimes with charred tips. A cook may remove the pan, rest briefly, then mash, puree, or incorporate into sauces, soups, or as a topping.

roasting_nut.progress_description: Start or intermediate states: Raw nuts are uniform in shape and size, with pale beige to light tan color, matte surface, and intact skins or shells. As heat is applied, they may swell slightly, skins blister or crack, and a thin oil sheen forms. Texture remains firm but less dry; kernels may loosen from shells. The roaster spreads nuts in a single layer, stirs or shakes, and adjusts heat and airflow to monitor progress.
roasting_nut.finished_description: End state: kernels uniformly golden brown, dry and crisp, with slight oil sheen; surface free of moisture, occasional crack in the shell or skin; size largely unchanged, shape intact but momentarily rounded or wrinkled; aroma nutty; no burned spots; in-shell nuts show split shells. For the roaster, cooling on a rack or tray, then tasting, seasoning or salting, and transferring to storage or packaging.

roasting_pumpkin.progress_description: Roasting start/intermediate: pumpkin pieces cut into wedges or cubes, skin on or off, different sizes. Cut faces show pale orange, fibrous flesh; surfaces may be slick with oil; edges softening; skin may blister; tray shows spacing, some steam. Aroma rising. The roaster uses tongs or a spatula to flip, stir, and redistribute pieces, apply oil or seasonings, and adjust oven temperature as needed.
roasting_pumpkin.finished_description: End state: pumpkin pieces (halves or 1–2 inch cubes) are fork-tender; interior bright orange, moist but not soggy; surface browned and lightly caramelized; skins softened for easy removal or crisped at the edges. Aroma nutty-sweet. If puréed, flesh is smooth, creamy, thick; if left in chunks, they hold shape but collapse easily under a fork. The cook may be removing from the oven, tasting, mashing, puréeing, or transferring to a bowl.

roasting_almond.progress_description: Start: almonds are oval, 1–2 cm, pale ivory to light tan, smooth and dry. In progress: faint browning begins at the edges; centers stay lighter with darker tips; a light oil sheen appears; warmth and nutty aroma intensify; skins may loosen. The roaster stirs or shakes the pan, adjusts heat, and keeps them in a single, even layer for even exposure.
roasting_almond.finished_description: End state: almonds evenly roasted, kernels intact but lightly curled; uniform size; color from light golden to deep brown with slightly darker rims; surface may be glossy from natural oils and show mild wrinkling; texture crisp and dry with a clean snap; aroma warm, toasty, nutty. The person finished roasting might be cooling on a wire rack, then salting/spicing or transferring to a container for storage.

roasting_chicken.progress_description: Start: whole chicken or pieces are pale pink, translucent, with damp skin and a soft, pliable shape; size near original. In progress: skin glistens as fat renders, surface moisture decreases, meat tightens, edges firm. Color shifts toward lighter, pale beige as interior stays juicy; juices bead or sizzle in the pan. The cook rearranges pieces, baste, or flip to promote even heat.
roasting_chicken.finished_description: End state: a whole roasted chicken (or parts) with golden-brown, crisp skin; meat white and firm to the bone with no pink; juices clear or pooled in the pan; rendered surface fat and slight shrinkage from roasting. Internal temperature 165°F (75°C) at the thickest part. The cook rests 10–15 minutes, then carves, plates, and drizzles pan juices.

roasting_vegetable.progress_description: Initial: cut pieces (sticks, rounds, wedges) of uniform size, raw and pale, firm to the touch, skin smooth and dry, coated with oil. In progress: surfaces redden to pale gold, browning or blistering appears, edges curl, moisture releases as steam; pieces remain distinct, not yet collapsing. Texture shifts from rigid to more yielding but still firm. The cook tosses, turns, and rearranges on the tray, checks with a fork, and reads heat, rotating as needed.
roasting_vegetable.finished_description: End state: uniform pieces browned and caramelized, lightly blistered skins, edges crisp, centers tender yet yielding when pierced. Colors range from golden to deep amber with occasional mahogany char. Surface glistens with reduced moisture and oil; no raw, pale spots. Pieces retain their shape though shrink slightly. When done, vegetables are fork-tender and ready to rest, then seasoned or served, often with a final sprinkle of herbs or citrus.

roasting_cauliflower.progress_description: Start/intermediate cauliflower in roasting: florets intact or broken into uniform chunks; pale white to ivory color; surface dry but slightly glossy from oil; edges may be smooth, with tips beginning to brown; stems tender but still firm; steamed look diminished; moisture beads appear; steam rising in pan; texture shifting from raw crisp to early softening near the core. The cook tosses pieces on a parchment sheet, drizzles oil, seasons, and rotates the tray during heating.
roasting_cauliflower.finished_description: End state: cauliflower florets are tender inside and lightly crisp at the edges, with surfaces ranging from pale ivory to golden-brown and caramelized tips. They may bear small char marks and a glossy oil glaze; florets stay intact but have shrunk slightly. Color and texture indicate roasted-through, not mushy. What the cook is doing: removing the tray from the oven, resting briefly, then tossing with lemon, herbs, or parmesan before plating or serving.

roasting_carrot.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: raw carrots, whole or cut into sticks or rounds; sizes vary but roughly uniform for even cooking. Color bright orange; surface smooth; texture firm to the bite; some moisture. In progress: on a parchment sheet, coated with oil and seasonings; glistening; edges may begin to soften or curl; pieces may shrink slightly; color remains orange to pale with surface matte sheen. Actions: person tosses, flips with tongs, checks tenderness, and adjusts heat or rack.
roasting_carrot.finished_description: End state: carrots are fork-tender, with lightly caramelized, browned edges. Size remains mostly intact but surfaces may be slightly shriveled; color deepens to orange with amber hues; a glassy sheen from natural sugars and a touch of charring on tips. Consistency ranges from soft to jammy in the center, with a slight bite near the core. After roasting, they might be plated, tossed with olive oil and herbs, or resting before serving.

roasting_hazelnut.progress_description: Start/intermediate state: pale beige to light tan hazelnut kernels with smooth, oval shapes. Some skins begin to loosen; surface may be dull and dry with a faint oil sheen developing. Size remains roughly constant, slight puffing as moisture evaporates. In-progress cues: even heating is attempted, kernels stirred or flipped, pan shaken, heat adjusted, to avoid scorching; occasional blistering or speckled discoloration appears.
roasting_hazelnut.finished_description: End state: Hazelnuts are uniformly golden to deep brown, with dry, crisp kernels that snap when bitten. Size is slightly reduced; shapes remain oval to teardrop with subtle wrinkling. Skins blister and may peel off. Oils surface, giving a faint sheen. If fully roasted, aroma is nutty and toasty; some nuts may darken more near their tips. After roasting, the person might be cooling on a rack, rubbing skins loose, or salting/grinding for paste.

roasting_turkey.progress_description: Start or in-progress turkey shows a whole bird on a rack, blocked in a roaster; skin pale to light pink and damp, with a rounded silhouette as fat renders. The breast and thighs appear plump; juices bead in the cavity and spill into the pan, sometimes steaming the air. The skin is not yet crisp; surface moisture glistens. The cook may be basting, rotating the pan, checking internal temperature with a probe, or tenting with foil.
roasting_turkey.finished_description: End state: a whole roasted turkey with a dome-shaped, evenly browned skin that is crisp to the touch; golden, with darker contour on the wings and drumsticks. The surface appears glossy from natural juices; the skin is taut, not pale. The meat is fully cooked: white breast and darker, opaque thigh, juices run clear when pierced; internal temperature at least 165°F (74°C) in the thickest parts. The cook is resting and/or carving on a board.

roasting_chickpea.progress_description: Start and intermediate states: chickpeas are dry, oval, about 6–8 mm; skins range from smooth to mildly wrinkled. They stay pale beige to light tan; some surface blistering may appear as moisture evaporates. They have not browned evenly yet. In progress, the roaster stirs or shakes the pan, rotates beans for even exposure, may add oil or salt, and watches color, aroma, and texture—without stating a final state.
roasting_chickpea.finished_description: End state: chickpeas are small, round-oval, about 0.5–1 cm, dry and crisp on the outside with a crackly shell; interior is firm and light within. Color ranges pale beige to golden-brown or amber, often wrinkled and sometimes split. Oil- or spice-coated varieties show a slight sheen. They should snap when bitten, not be soft or mushy. After roasting, the person is cooling them or tossing with salt/spices in a bowl.

roasting_corn.progress_description:
- Start state: Husk intact; silk present; kernels pale yellow; cob cool to the touch.
- Early progress: Heat steams; husk loosens; kernels plump and slightly translucent; surface glossy.
- Mid progress: Surfaces blister; tiny brown specks appear at tips; aroma develops; steam escapes; cob warms.
- Actions: Roaster rotates with tongs; adjusts flame; peels back the husk to check progress; light oil or butter brushed on.
roasting_corn.finished_description: End state: corn kernels on the cob are golden-brown with occasional char, plump and glistening from caramelized sugars; texture tender with slight crisp edges; kernels may vary from light tan to deep amber. When off the cob, kernels are separated and ready to eat. The person finished roasting might be cooling the ears, brushing on butter, sprinkling salt, or slicing kernels onto a plate or into bowls.

roasting_asparagus.progress_description: Raw asparagus: bright green spears, 6–10 inches, 0.3–0.5 inch thick, trimmed ends, uniform size, laid on a sheet with oil sheen and a pinch of salt. In progress: surfaces glisten, tips intact, spears begin to curl slightly, outer skin shows subtle wrinkling; color remains largely green with a hint of dullness. The cook drizzles oil, tosses, spaces them evenly, and flips midway while monitoring the oven.
roasting_asparagus.finished_description: End state: evenly sized spears, 0.5–1 cm thick, tender with a slight bite. Color bright green with golden-brown caramelization and crisp, browned tips; stalks may have slight wrinkling where thickest. Surface glistens with oil and small char marks appear. For the person: they remove from oven, rest briefly, then plate and optionally finish with lemon zest, parmesan, or salt before serving as a side dish.

roasting_broccoli.progress_description: Start: broccoli with tight, bright-green florets and firm, pale-green stems; surface moist, size unchanged. In progress: florets stay green but gloss with oil, surfaces become a bit wrinkled; edges may blister; stems soften; steam rises as heat penetrates. Actions: oven preheated, florets spread in a single layer, tossed or flipped with tongs or spatula, timer checked, tray shaken for even exposure.
roasting_broccoli.finished_description: End state of roasting broccoli: florets golden-brown with caramelized, blistered edges; some dark spots; surface slightly crisp while inner tissue remains tender; stalks softened but still have a bite; overall shrinkage makes pieces look smaller. The cook may be removing the tray from the oven, transferring to a plate, and finishing with salt, pepper, lemon juice, or parmesan, then letting it rest briefly before serving.

roasting_squash.progress_description: Start or in-progress roasting squash shows: a whole squash with glossy skin or cut pieces (wedges or cubes), sizes variable, skin color matching variety, flesh pale and firm, seeds visible in halves. In-progress signs: oil-coated surfaces, visible steam, and gloss; cut faces becoming translucent; edges softening and tinting at the margins; faint caramelization starting on exposed edges. The cook may flip, rotate, or spread pieces for even heat, adjust oven rack, and monitor aroma and timers.
roasting_squash.finished_description: End state of roasted squash: flesh fork-tender and steaming, easily scooped from a softened skin, often halved or wedged; color ranges from bright orange to deep caramel on the cut sides; flesh may be creamy, slightly jammy, or fluffy depending on variety; edges caramelized with blistered brown specks; surface glistening with released juices; seeds roasted in the cavity may be browned. The cook may be resting, scooping, mashing, or pureeing the flesh, seasoning, or serving.

roasting_beet.progress_description: Start: beets are whole, round to oblong, with tight red-purple skin and hard, dense flesh; little to no color change. In mid-roast, skins blister or split, a dull sheen appears, and the core softens yet remains firm; moisture beads and steam escapes from the surface. The roaster trims greens, rinses if needed, tosses with oil or salt, and places beets on a sheet, oven-hot, possibly turning them midway.
roasting_beet.finished_description: Finished roasting, beets are very tender and fork-pierced; skin loosens and can be rubbed away. Shape remains roughly round to oval, though softened and slightly collapsed in places; flesh is deep ruby-purple, uniform, and creamy-soft; outer skin may be slightly wrinkled or dry from roasting. Size is a bit smaller due to moisture loss; juices may pool. The person finished roasting is likely cooling and peeling, then slicing, dicing, or mashing for salads, sides, or purees.

roasting_mushroom.progress_description: In early to mid-roast: mushrooms (sliced or whole) 2–4 cm pieces are pale to light brown, edges just starting to brown, surfaces glossy with oil. They soften but hold shape; moisture beads or steams in the pan; occasional curling. The cook lays them in a single layer, maintains moderate heat, and stirs or flips them, allowing water to evaporate and fat to render, while seasoning is added as color begins to deepen.
roasting_mushroom.finished_description: End state: mushrooms browned all over, with golden to deep caramel color and blistered edges; caps may shrink and curl slightly. Moisture largely evaporated; surface dryish with crisp edges. Interior is tender and juicy, rich in umami; overall texture ranges from crisp-on-the-outside to soft inside. Color gold-to-brown; size slightly reduced. They’re usually finished by removing from heat, tasting, then plating or tossing with oil/herbs and serving.
